{"tools":[{"name":"microsoft_docs_search","description":"Search official Microsoft/Azure documentation to find the most relevant and trustworthy content for a user's query. This tool returns up to 10 high-quality content chunks (each max 500 tokens), extracted from Microsoft Learn and other official sources. toolFormerData.result: {"selectedTool":"microsoft_docs_search","result":"{\"content\":[{\"type\":\"text\",\"text\":\"{\\\"results\\\":[{\\\"title\\\":\\\"NTFS overview\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# NTFS overview\\\\nNew Technology File System (NTFS) is the default file system for modern Windows-based operating system (OS). It provides advanced features, including security descriptors, encryption, disk quotas, and support for rich metadata, enhancing both security and data management. Additionally, NTFS seamlessly integrates with Cluster Shared Volumes (CSV), allowing highly available storage that multiple nodes in a failover cluster can access concurrently. This integration ensures continuous data availability and resilience.\\\\n## Increased reliability\\\\nNTFS enhances reliability by maintaining a transaction-based log file and checkpoint information. If a system failure occurs, NTFS uses this log to automatically restore file system consistency during the next startup, minimizing the risk of data loss. When a bad sector is detected, NTFS dynamically remaps the affected cluster to a healthy one, marks the original cluster as unusable, and ensures that data is preserved. For example, after a system crash, NTFS can recover changes by replaying its transaction log, helping to maintain data integrity and reduce downtime.\\\\nNTFS includes a feature called [self-healing NTFS](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/previous-versions/windows/it-pro/windows-server-2008-r2-and-2008/cc771388%28v=ws.10%29), which automatically detects and repairs minor file system corruption in the background, without requiring the volume to be taken offline. This proactive approach helps maintain data integrity and minimizes disruptions to users and applications.\\\\nFor more significant file system corruption, the \\\\u0060chkdsk\\\\u0060 utility can scan and repair NTFS volumes while keeping them online, minimizing downtime. The only period the volume might be unavailable is during the phase required to restore data consistency. When NTFS is used with CSV, repairs can be performed without any downtime, ensuring continuous availability. To learn more, see [NTFS Health and Chkdsk](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/previous-versions/windows/it-pro/windows-server-2012-r2-and-2012/hh831536%28v%3dws.11%29).\\\",\\\"contentUrl\\\":\\\"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/storage/file-server/ntfs-overview\\\"},{\\\"title\\\":\\\"Overview of FAT, HPFS, and NTFS File Systems\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Overview of FAT, HPFS, and NTFS File Systems\\\\n## NTFS overview\\\\nFrom a user\\\\u0027s point of view, NTFS continues to organize files into directories, which, like HPFS, are sorted. However, unlike FAT or HPFS, there are no \\\\u0022special\\\\u0022 objects on the disk and there is no dependence on the underlying hardware, such as 512-byte sectors. In addition, there are no special locations on the disk, such as FAT tables or HPFS Super Blocks.\\\\nThe goals of NTFS are to provide:\\\\n1. Reliability, which is especially desirable for high end systems and file servers\\\\n2. A platform for added functionality\\\\n3. Support POSIX requirements\\\\n4. Removal of the limitations of the FAT and HPFS file systems\\\\n### Reliability\\\\nTo ensure reliability of NTFS, three major areas were addressed: recoverability, removal of fatal single sector failures, and hot fixing.\\\\nNTFS is a recoverable file system because it keeps track of transactions against the file system. When a CHKDSK is performed on FAT or HPFS, the consistency of pointers within the directory, allocation, and file tables are being checked. Under NTFS, a log of transactions against these components is maintained so that CHKDSK need only roll back transactions to the last commit point in order to recover consistency within the file system.\\\\nUnder FAT or HPFS, if a sector that is the location of one of the file system\\\\u0027s special objects fails, then a single sector failure will occur. NTFS avoids this in two ways: first, by not using special objects on the disk and tracking and protecting all objects that are on the disk. Secondly, under NTFS, multiple copies (the number depends on the volume size) of the Master File Table are kept.\\\\nSimilar to OS/2 versions of HPFS, NTFS supports hot fixing.\\\\n### Added functionality\\\\nOne of the major design goals of Windows NT at every level is to provide a platform that can be added to and built upon, and NTFS is no exception. NTFS provides a rich and flexible platform for other file systems to be able to use. In addition, NTFS fully supports the Windows NT security model and supports multiple data streams. No longer is a data file a single stream of data. Finally, under NTFS, a user can add his or her own user-defined attributes to a file.\\\\n### POSIX support\\\\nNTFS is the most POSIX.1 compliant of the supported file systems because it supports the following POSIX.1 requirements:\\\\nCase-sensitive naming:\\\",\\\"contentUrl\\\":\\\"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/troubleshoot/windows-client/backup-and-storage/fat-hpfs-and-ntfs-file-systems#ntfs-overview\\\"},{\\\"title\\\":\\\"Overview of FAT, HPFS, and NTFS File Systems\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Overview of FAT, HPFS, and NTFS File Systems\\\\n## NTFS overview\\\\nUnder POSIX, README.TXT, Readme.txt, and readme.txt are all different files.\\\\nAdditional time stamp:\\\\nThe additional time stamp supplies the time at which the file was last accessed.\\\\nHard links:\\\\nA hard link is when two different filenames, which can be located in different directories, point to the same data.\\\\n### Remove limitations\\\\nFirst, NTFS has greatly increased the size of files and volumes, so that they can now be up to 2^64 bytes (16 exabytes or 18,446,744,073,709,551,616 bytes). NTFS has also returned to the FAT concept of clusters in order to avoid HPFS problem of a fixed sector size. This was done because Windows NT is a portable operating system and different disk technology is likely to be encountered at some point. Therefore, 512 bytes per sector was viewed as having a large possibility of not always being a good fit for the allocation. This was accomplished by allowing the cluster to be defined as multiples of the hardware\\\\u0027s natural allocation size. Finally, in NTFS all filenames are Unicode based, and 8.3 filenames are kept along with long filenames.\\\\n### Advantages of NTFS\\\\nNTFS is best for use on volumes of about 400 MB or more. This is because performance does not degrade under NTFS, as it does under FAT, with larger volume sizes.\\\\nThe recoverability designed into NTFS is such that a user should never have to run any sort of disk repair utility on an NTFS partition. For additional advantages of NTFS, see the following:\\\\n1. Windows NT Server \\\\u0022Concepts and Planning Guide,\\\\u0022 Chapter 5, section titled \\\\u0022Choosing a File System\\\\u0022\\\\n2. Windows NT Workstation 4.0 Resource Kit, Chapter 18, \\\\u0022Choosing a File System\\\\u0022\\\\n3. Windows NT Server 4.0 Resource Kit \\\\u0022Resource Guide,\\\\u0022 Chapter 3, section titled \\\\u0022Which File System to Use on Which Volumes\\\\u0022\\\\n### Disadvantages of NTFS\\\\nIt is not recommended to use NTFS on a volume that is smaller than approximately 400 MB, because of the amount of space overhead involved in NTFS. This space overhead is in the form of NTFS system files that typically use at least 4 MB of drive space on a 100-MB partition.\\\",\\\"contentUrl\\\":\\\"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/troubleshoot/windows-client/backup-and-storage/fat-hpfs-and-ntfs-file-systems#ntfs-overview\\\"},{\\\"title\\\":\\\"General Guidelines for Improving Operating System Performance\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# General Guidelines for Improving Operating System Performance\\\\n## Use the NTFS file system on all volumes\\\\nWindows Server offers multiple file system types for formatting drives, including NTFS, FAT, and FAT32. NTFS should always be the file system of choice for servers.\\\\nNTFS offers considerable performance benefits over the FAT and FAT32 file systems and should be used exclusively on Windows servers. In addition, NTFS offers many security, scalability, stability and recoverability benefits over FAT and FAT32.\\\\nUnder previous versions of Windows, FAT and FAT32 were often implemented for smaller volumes (say \\\\u003C500 MB) because they were often faster in such situations. With disk storage relatively inexpensive today and operating systems and applications pushing drive capacity to a maximum, it is unlikely that such small volumes will be in use. FAT32 scales better than FAT on larger volumes but is still not an appropriate file system for Windows servers.\\\\nFAT and FAT32 have often been implemented in the past as they were seen as more easily recoverable and manageable with native DOS tools in the event of a problem with a volume. Today, with the various NTFS recoverability tools built both natively into the operating system and available as third-party utilities available, there should no longer be a valid argument for not using NTFS for file systems.\\\\n## Do not use NTFS file compression\\\\nThough using NTFS file system compression is an easy way to reduce space on volumes, it is not appropriate for enterprise file servers. Implementing compression places an unnecessary overhead on the CPU for all disk operations and is best avoided. Think about options for adding additional disks, near-line storage or consider archiving data before seriously considering file system compression.\\\",\\\"contentUrl\\\":\\\"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/biztalk/technical-guides/general-guidelines-for-improving-operating-system-performance#use-the-ntfs-file-system-on-all-volumes\\\"},{\\\"title\\\":\\\"Overview of FAT, HPFS, and NTFS File Systems\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Overview of FAT, HPFS, and NTFS File Systems\\\\n## NTFS overview\\\\nCurrently, there is no file encryption built into NTFS. Therefore, someone can boot under MS-DOS, or another operating system, and use a low-level disk editing utility to view data stored on an NTFS volume.\\\\nIt is not possible to format a floppy disk with the NTFS file system; Windows NT formats all floppy disks with the FAT file system because the overhead involved in NTFS will not fit onto a floppy disk.\\\\nFor further discussion of NTFS disadvantages, see the following:\\\\n1. Windows NT Server \\\\u0022Concepts and Planning Guide,\\\\u0022 Chapter 5, section titled \\\\u0022Choosing a File System\\\\u0022\\\\n2. Windows NT Workstation 4.0 Resource Kit, Chapter 18, \\\\u0022Choosing a File System\\\\u0022\\\\n3. Windows NT Server 4.0 Resource Kit \\\\u0022Resource Guide,\\\\u0022 Chapter 3, section titled \\\\u0022Which File System to Use on Which Volumes\\\\u0022\\\\n### NTFS naming conventions\\\\nFile and directory names can be up to 255 characters long, including any extensions. Names preserve case, but are not case-sensitive. NTFS makes no distinction of filenames based on case. Names can contain any characters except for the following:\\\\n\\\\u0060? \\\\u0022 / \\\\\\\\ \\\\u003C \\\\u003E * | :\\\\u0060\\\\nCurrently, from the command line, you can only create file names of up to 253 characters.\\\\nNote\\\\nUnderlying hardware limitations may impose additional partition size limitations in any file system. Particularly, a boot partition can be only 7.8 GB in size, and there is a 2-terabyte limitation in the partition table.\\\\nFor more information about the supported file systems for Windows NT, see the Windows NT Resource Kit.\\\",\\\"contentUrl\\\":\\\"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/troubleshoot/windows-client/backup-and-storage/fat-hpfs-and-ntfs-file-systems#ntfs-overview\\\"},{\\\"title\\\":\\\"File and Directory Linking\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# File and Directory Linking\\\\nThe NTFS file system provides the ability to create a system representation of a file or directory in a location in the directory structure that is different from the file or directory object that is being linked to. This process is called linking. There are two types of links supported in the NTFS file system: [hard links and junctions](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/fileio/hard-links-and-junctions).\\\\nThe NTFS file system also provides the [distributed link tracking service](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/fileio/distributed-link-tracking-and-object-identifiers), which automatically tracks links as they are moved.\\\",\\\"contentUrl\\\":\\\"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/fileio/file-and-directory-linking\\\"},{\\\"title\\\":\\\"Master File Table (Local File Systems)\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Master File Table (Local File Systems)\\\\nThe NTFS file system contains a file called the *master file table*, or MFT. There is at least one entry in the MFT for every file on an NTFS file system volume, including the MFT itself. All information about a file, including its size, time and date stamps, permissions, and data content, is stored either in MFT entries, or in space outside the MFT that is described by MFT entries.\\\\nAs files are added to an NTFS file system volume, more entries are added to the MFT and the MFT increases in size. When files are deleted from an NTFS file system volume, their MFT entries are marked as free and may be reused. However, disk space that has been allocated for these entries is not reallocated, and the size of the MFT does not decrease.\\\\nThe NTFS file system reserves space for the MFT to keep the MFT as contiguous as possible as it grows. The space reserved by the NTFS file system for the MFT in each volume is called the MFT zone. Space for file and directories are also allocated from this space, but only after all of the volume space outside of the MFT zone has been allocated.\\\\nDepending on the average file size and other variables, either the reserved MFT zone or the unreserved space on the disk may be allocated first as the disk fills to capacity. Volumes with a small number of relatively large files will allocate the unreserved space first, while volumes with a large number of relatively small files allocate the MFT zone first. In either case, fragmentation of the MFT starts to take place when one region or the other becomes fully allocated. If the unreserved space is completely allocated, space for user files and directories will be allocated from the MFT zone. If the MFT zone is completely allocated, space for new MFT entries will be allocated from the unreserved space.\\\\nThe MFT itself can be defragmented. To reduce the chance of the MFT zone becoming fully allocated before the defragmentation process is complete, leave as much space at the beginning of the MFT zone as possible before defragmenting the volume. If the MFT zone becomes fully allocated before defragmentation has completed, there must be unallocated space outside of the MFT zone.\\\",\\\"contentUrl\\\":\\\"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/fileio/master-file-table\\\"},{\\\"title\\\":\\\"Managing Disk Quotas\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Managing Disk Quotas\\\\nThe NTFS file system supports *disk quotas*, which allow administrators to control the amount of data that each user can store on an NTFS file system volume. Administrators can optionally configure the system to log an event when users are near their quota, and to deny further disk space to users who exceed their quota. Administrators can also generate reports, and use the event monitor to track quota issues.\\\\nYou can determine whether a file system supports disk quotas by calling the [**GetVolumeInformation**](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/desktop/api/FileAPI/nf-fileapi-getvolumeinformationa) function and examining the **FILE\\\\\\\\_VOLUME\\\\\\\\_QUOTAS** bit flag.\\\",\\\"contentUrl\\\":\\\"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/fileio/managing-disk-quotas\\\"},{\\\"title\\\":\\\"NTFS overview\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# NTFS overview\\\\n## Maximum file name and path\\\\nNTFS supports long file names and extended-length paths, with the following maximum values:\\\\n1. **Support for long file names, with backward compatibility**: NTFS supports long file names, storing an 8.3 alias on disk (in Unicode) to provide compatibility with file systems that impose an 8.3 limit on file names and extensions. If needed, for performance reasons, you can selectively disable 8.3 aliasing on individual NTFS volumes in Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows 8, and more recent versions of the Windows OS. In Windows Server 2008 R2 and later systems, short names are disabled by default when a volume is formatted using the OS. For application compatibility, short names still are enabled on the system volume.\\\\n2. **Support for extended-length paths**: Many Windows API functions have Unicode versions that allow an extended-length path of approximately 32,767 characters. That total is beyond the 260-character path limit defined by the MAX\\\\\\\\_PATH setting. For detailed file name and path format requirements, and guidance for implementing extended-length paths, see [Naming files, paths, and namespaces](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/fileio/naming-a-file).\\\\n3. **Clustered storage**: When used in failover clusters, NTFS supports continuously available volumes that can be accessed by multiple cluster nodes simultaneously when used with the CSV file system. To learn more, see [Use Cluster Shared Volumes in a failover cluster](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/failover-clustering/failover-cluster-csvs).\\\\n## Flexible allocation of capacity\\\\nIf the space on a volume is limited, NTFS provides the following ways to work with the storage capacity of a server:\\\\n1. Use disk quotas to track and control disk space usage on NTFS volumes for individual users.\\\\n2. Use file system compression to maximize the amount of data that can be stored.\\\\n3. Increase the size of an NTFS volume by adding unallocated space from the same disk or from a different disk.\\\\n4. Mount a volume at any empty folder on a local NTFS volume if you run out of drive letters or need to create extra space that is accessible from an existing folder.\\\",\\\"contentUrl\\\":\\\"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/storage/file-server/ntfs-overview#maximum-file-name-and-path\\\"},{\\\"title\\\":\\\"File System Functionality Comparison\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# File System Functionality Comparison\\\\n## Compression\\\\n| Feature | NTFS | exFAT | UDF | FAT32| \\\\n|  --- | --- | --- | --- | ---  |\\\\n| Built-in compression | Yes | No | No | No |\\\\n\\\\n## Quotas\\\\n| Feature | NTFS | exFAT | UDF | FAT32| \\\\n|  --- | --- | --- | --- | ---  |\\\\n| User-level disk space | Yes | No | No | No |\\\\n| Directory-level disk space | No (see note below) | No | No | No |\\\\n\\\\n**Note** The directory-level disk space quotas feature on NTFS is available through the File Server Resource Manager.\\\\n## Single-Instance Store\\\\n| Feature | NTFS | exFAT | UDF | FAT32| \\\\n|  --- | --- | --- | --- | ---  |\\\\n| File level | No (see note below) | No | No | No |\\\\n\\\\n**Note** Single-instance store for NTFS is available as part of the Single Instance Storage feature in Windows Server.\\\",\\\"contentUrl\\\":\\\"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/fileio/filesystem-functionality-comparison#compression\\\"}]}\"}],\"structuredContent\":{\"results\":[{\"title\":\"NTFS overview\",\"content\":\"# NTFS overview\\nNew Technology File System (NTFS) is the default file system for modern Windows-based operating system (OS). Additionally, NTFS seamlessly integrates with Cluster Shared Volumes (CSV), allowing highly available storage that multiple nodes in a failover cluster can access concurrently. Names preserve case, but are not case-sensitive. NTFS makes no distinction of filenames based on case. Names can contain any characters except for the following:\\n`? \\\" / \\\\ < > * | :`\\nCurrently, from the command line, you can only create file names of up to 253 characters.\\nNote\\nUnderlying hardware limitations may impose additional partition size limitations in any file system. Particularly, a boot partition can be only 7.8 GB in size, and there is a 2-terabyte limitation in the partition table.\\nFor more information about the supported file systems for Windows NT, see the Windows NT Resource Kit.\",\"contentUrl\":\"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/troubleshoot/windows-client/backup-and-storage/fat-hpfs-and-ntfs-file-systems#ntfs-overview\"},{\"title\":\"File and Directory Linking\",\"content\":\"# File and Directory Linking\\nThe NTFS file system provides the ability to create a system representation of a file or directory in a location in the directory structure that is different from the file or directory object that is being linked to. This process is called linking. There are two types of links supported in the NTFS file system: [hard links and junctions](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/fileio/hard-links-and-junctions).\\nThe NTFS file system also provides the [distributed link tracking service](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/fileio/distributed-link-tracking-and-object-identifiers), which automatically tracks links as they are moved.\",\"contentUrl\":\"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/fileio/file-and-directory-linking\"},{\"title\":\"Master File Table (Local File Systems)\",\"content\":\"# Master File Table (Local File Systems)\\nThe NTFS file system contains a file called the *master file table*, or MFT. There is at least one entry in the MFT for every file on an NTFS file system volume, including the MFT itself. All information about a file, including its size, time and date stamps, permissions, and data content, is stored either in MFT entries, or in space outside the MFT that is described by MFT entries.\\nAs files are added to an NTFS file system volume, more entries are added to the MFT and the MFT increases in size. When files are deleted from an NTFS file system volume, their MFT entries are marked as free and may be reused. However, disk space that has been allocated for these entries is not reallocated, and the size of the MFT does not decrease.\\nThe NTFS file system reserves space for the MFT to keep the MFT as contiguous as possible as it grows. The space reserved by the NTFS file system for the MFT in each volume is called the MFT zone. Space for file and directories are also allocated from this space, but only after all of the volume space outside of the MFT zone has been allocated.\\nDepending on the average file size and other variables, either the reserved MFT zone or the unreserved space on the disk may be allocated first as the disk fills to capacity. Volumes with a small number of relatively large files will allocate the unreserved space first, while volumes with a large number of relatively small files allocate the MFT zone first. In either case, fragmentation of the MFT starts to take place when one region or the other becomes fully allocated. If the unreserved space is completely allocated, space for user files and directories will be allocated from the MFT zone. If the MFT zone is completely allocated, space for new MFT entries will be allocated from the unreserved space.\\nThe MFT itself can be defragmented. To reduce the chance of the MFT zone becoming fully allocated before the defragmentation process is complete, leave as much space at the beginning of the MFT zone as possible before defragmenting the volume. If the MFT zone becomes fully allocated before defragmentation has completed, there must be unallocated space outside of the MFT zone.\",\"contentUrl\":\"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/fileio/master-file-table\"},{\"title\":\"Managing Disk Quotas\",\"content\":\"# Managing Disk Quotas\\nThe NTFS file system supports *disk quotas*, which allow administrators to control the amount of data that each user can store on an NTFS file system volume. Administrators can optionally configure the system to log an event when users are near their quota, and to deny further disk space to users who exceed their quota. Administrators can also generate reports, and use the event monitor to track quota issues.\\nYou can determine whether a file system supports disk quotas by calling the [**GetVolumeInformation**](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/desktop/api/FileAPI/nf-fileapi-getvolumeinformationa) function and examining the **FILE\\\\_VOLUME\\\\_QUOTAS** bit flag.\",\"contentUrl\":\"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/fileio/managing-disk-quotas\"},{\"title\":\"NTFS overview\",\"content\":\"# NTFS overview\\n## Maximum file name and path\\nNTFS supports long file names and extended-length paths, with the following maximum values:\\n1. **Support for long file names, with backward compatibility**: NTFS supports long file names, storing an 8.3 alias on disk (in Unicode) to provide compatibility with file systems that impose an 8.3 limit on file names and extensions. If needed, for performance reasons, you can selectively disable 8.3 aliasing on individual NTFS volumes in Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows 8, and more recent versions of the Windows OS. In Windows Server 2008 R2 and later systems, short names are disabled by default when a volume is formatted using the OS. For application compatibility, short names still are enabled on the system volume.\\n2. **Support for extended-length paths**: Many Windows API functions have Unicode versions that allow an extended-length path of approximately 32,767 characters. That total is beyond the 260-character path limit defined by the MAX\\\\_PATH setting. For detailed file name and path format requirements, and guidance for implementing extended-length paths, see [Naming files, paths, and namespaces](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/fileio/naming-a-file).\\n3. **Clustered storage**: When used in failover clusters, NTFS supports continuously available volumes that can be accessed by multiple cluster nodes simultaneously when used with the CSV file system. To learn more, see [Use Cluster Shared Volumes in a failover cluster](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/failover-clustering/failover-cluster-csvs).\\n## Flexible allocation of capacity\\nIf the space on a volume is limited, NTFS provides the following ways to work with the storage capacity of a server:\\n1. Use disk quotas to track and control disk space usage on NTFS volumes for individual users.\\n2. Use file system compression to maximize the amount of data that can be stored.\\n3. Increase the size of an NTFS volume by adding unallocated space from the same disk or from a different disk.\\n4. Mount a volume at any empty folder on a local NTFS volume if you run out of drive letters or need to create extra space that is accessible from an existing folder.\",\"contentUrl\":\"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/storage/file-server/ntfs-overview#maximum-file-name-and-path\"},{\"title\":\"File System Functionality Comparison\",\"content\":\"# File System Functionality Comparison\\n## Compression\\n| Feature | NTFS | exFAT | UDF | FAT32| \\n|  --- | --- | --- | --- | ---  |\\n| Built-in compression | Yes | No | No | No |\\n\\n## Quotas\\n| Feature | NTFS | exFAT | UDF | FAT32| \\n|  --- | --- | --- | --- | ---  |\\n| User-level disk space | Yes | No | No | No |\\n| Directory-level disk space | No (see note below) | No | No | No |\\n\\n**Note** The directory-level disk space quotas feature on NTFS is available through the File Server Resource Manager.\\n## Single-Instance Store\\n| Feature | NTFS | exFAT | UDF | FAT32| \\n|  --- | --- | --- | --- | ---  |\\n| File level | No (see note below) | No | No | No |\\n\\n**Note** Single-instance store for NTFS is available as part of the Single Instance Storage feature in Windows Server.\",\"contentUrl\":\"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/fileio/filesystem-functionality-comparison#compression\"}]}}"}

data.text:
Here's the comprehensive **NTFS (New Technology File System)** documentation from Microsoft Learn:

---

## Overview

NTFS is the **default file system for modern Windows operating systems**. It provides advanced features including:

- Security descriptors
- Encryption
- Disk quotas
- Rich metadata support
- Integration with Cluster Shared Volumes (CSV) for high-availability storage

---

## Key Features

### Increased Reliability

| Feature | Description |
|---------|-------------|
| **Transaction Log** | Maintains a transaction-based log file and checkpoint information to automatically restore file system consistency after crashes |
| **Bad Sector Handling** | Dynamically remaps affected clusters to healthy ones and marks originals as unusable |
| **Self-Healing NTFS** | Automatically detects and repairs minor corruption in the background without taking the volume offline |
| **Online `chkdsk`** | Scans and repairs volumes while keeping them online (minimal downtime) |

### Increased Security

- **Granular ACL Permissions**: Assign detailed read/write/modify permissions per user/group on files and folders
- **BitLocker Integration**: Works with BitLocker Drive Encryption for hardware-based data protection using TPM

---

## Volume and File Size Limits

NTFS supports volumes up to **8 PB** (Windows Server 2019+ / Windows 10 1709+). Earlier versions support up to 256 TB.

| Cluster Size | Max Volume/File Size |
|--------------|---------------------|
| 4 KB (default) | 16 TB |
| 8 KB | 32 TB |
| 16 KB | 64 TB |
| 32 KB | 128 TB |
| 64 KB | 256 TB |
| 128 KB | 512 TB |
| 256 KB | 1 PB |
| 512 KB | 2 PB |
| 1024 KB | 4 PB |
| 2048 KB (max) | **8 PB** |

---

## Formatting for Large Files

For volumes hosting large files (e.g., `.vhdx` > 1 TB) or Data Deduplication:

**PowerShell:**
```powershell
Format-Volume -DriveLetter D -FileSystem NTFS -AllocationUnitSize 65536 -UseLargeFRS
```

**Command Prompt:**
```cmd
format D: /l /a:64k
```

---

## File Name and Path Limits

| Feature | Limit |
|---------|-------|
| File name length | Up to 255 characters |
| Standard path length | 260 characters (MAX_PATH) |
| Extended-length paths | ~32,767 characters (Unicode API) |
| 8.3 compatibility | Stores short aliases for legacy compatibility |

---

## Flexible Capacity Management

- **Disk Quotas**: Track and control per-user disk space usage
- **Compression**: Built-in file system compression (note: adds CPU overhead)
- **Volume Expansion**: Add unallocated space from same or different disk
- **Mount Points**: Mount volumes at empty folders (bypass drive letter limits)

---

## Additional Concepts

From the search results, other important NTFS components include:

| Component | Description |
|-----------|-------------|
| **Master File Table (MFT)** | Core database storing all file metadata, permissions, timestamps, and data content |
| **Hard Links & Junctions** | Create multiple directory entries pointing to same data |
| **Distributed Link Tracking** | Automatically tracks links when files move |

---

**Source**: [NTFS Overview - Microsoft Learn](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/storage/file-server/ntfs-overview)

codeBlocks.content: Format-Volume -DriveLetter D -FileSystem NTFS -AllocationUnitSize 65536 -UseLargeFRS
format D: /l /a:64k

# start-llm.ps1 - Launch local LLM server for Cursor
# RTX 4060 8GB VRAM-safe settings

$ErrorActionPreference = "Stop"
Set-Location $PSScriptRoot

$model = "qwen2.5-coder-7b-instruct-q4_k_m.gguf"

if (-not (Test-Path $model)) {
    Write-Host "ERROR: Model not found: $model" -ForegroundColor Red
    Write-Host "Download from: https://huggingface.co/Qwen/Qwen2.5-Coder-7B-Instruct-GGUF"
    exit 1
}

Write-Host "Starting llamafile server..." -ForegroundColor Cyan
Write-Host "Model: $model"
Write-Host "Endpoint: http://127.0.0.1:8080/v1"
Write-Host ""
Write-Host "Press Ctrl+C to stop"
Write-Host ""

# RTX 4060 8GB VRAM-safe settings:
# -ngl 99       = Full GPU offload (all layers to VRAM)
# -c 4096       = 4K context (safer than 8K on 8GB with Windows+Cursor overhead)
# --host/--port = OpenAI-compatible API on localhost
# --nobrowser   = Silent start (no browser tab)

.\llamafile.exe `
    -m $model `
    -ngl 99 `
    -c 4096 `
    --host 127.0.0.1 `
    --port 8080

| Addition | Content |
|----------|---------|
| **GENERAL Scripts, SPECIFIC Tasks** | New section explaining scripts are composable building blocks, not task-specific solutions |
| **Fravia Search Strategy** | 5-step methodology for search planning before execution |
| **Suckless Principles** | Anti-patterns (UUoC, unnecessary chains) with correct alternatives |
| **Search Tool Priority** | Ordered list: grep > find > git grep > semantic > web |
| **PowerShell Equivalents** | Same principles applied to PowerShell pipelines |
| **The Suckless Test** | 5 questions to ask before executing command chains |
| **Updated DO/DO NOT** | Aligned with new principles |

toolFormerData.result:
{"diff":{"chunks":[{"diffString":"- 
+ # test-api.ps1 - Test llamafile OpenAI-compatible API
+ 
+ $uri = "http://127.0.0.1:8080/v1/chat/completions"
+ 
+ $body = @{
+     model = "qwen2.5-coder-7b-instruct-q4_k_m.gguf"
+     messages = @(
+         @{
+             role = "user"
+             content = "Write a hello world function in C. Output only code, no explanation."
+         }
+     )
+     temperature = 0.2
+     max_tokens = 200
+ } | ConvertTo-Json -Depth 10
+ 
+ Write-Host "Testing llamafile API..." -ForegroundColor Cyan
+ Write-Host "POST $uri"
+ Write-Host ""
+ 
+ try {
+     $response = Invoke-RestMethod -Uri $uri -Method POST -Body $body -ContentType "application/json"
+     Write-Host "Response:" -ForegroundColor Green
+     Write-Host $response.choices[0].message.content
+ } catch {
+     Write-Host "ERROR: $($_.Exception.Message)" -ForegroundColor Red
+     Write-Host "Is the server running? Start with: .\start-llm.ps1"
+ }
+ ","oldStart":1,"newStart":1,"oldLines":1,"newLines":29,"linesRemoved":1,"linesAdded":29}],"editor":"EDITOR_AI"},"shouldAutoFixLints":true,"resultForModel":"Wrote contents to C:\llamafile-llm\test-api.ps1.","contentsAfterEdit":"# test-api.ps1 - Test llamafile OpenAI-compatible API

$uri = "http://127.0.0.1:8080/v1/chat/completions"

$body = @{
    model = "qwen2.5-coder-7b-instruct-q4_k_m.gguf"
    messages = @(
        @{
            role = "user"
            content = "Write a hello world function in C. Output only code, no explanation."
        }
    )
    temperature = 0.2
    max_tokens = 200
} | ConvertTo-Json -Depth 10

Write-Host "Testing llamafile API..." -ForegroundColor Cyan
Write-Host "POST $uri"
Write-Host ""

try {
    $response = Invoke-RestMethod -Uri $uri -Method POST -Body $body -ContentType "application/json"
    Write-Host "Response:" -ForegroundColor Green
    Write-Host $response.choices[0].message.content
} catch {
    Write-Host "ERROR: $($_.Exception.Message)" -ForegroundColor Red
    Write-Host "Is the server running? Start with: .\start-llm.ps1"
}

"}

toolFormerData.result: {"selectedTool":"microsoft_docs_search","result":"{\"content\":[{\"type\":\"text\",\"text\":\"{\\\"results\\\":[{\\\"title\\\":\\\"Resolved issues in Windows 11, version 21H2\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Resolved issues in Windows 11, version 21H2\\\\n## Issue details\\\\nDevices attempting to install the January 2024 Windows Recovery Environment update ([KB5034440](https://support.microsoft.com/help/5034440)) might display an error related to the size of the Recovery Environment\\\\u0027s partition. The [Windows Recovery Environment (WinRE)](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/manufacture/desktop/windows-recovery-environment--windows-re--technical-reference?view=windows-11) is used to repair or recover from issues affecting Windows.\\\\nResulting from this error, the following message might be displayed.\\\\n1. \\\\u200B\\\\u00220x80070643 - ERROR\\\\\\\\_INSTALL\\\\\\\\_FAILURE\\\\u0022\\\\n**Important**: If your Windows device does not have a recovery environment configured, you do not need this update ([KB5034440](https://support.microsoft.com/help/5034440)). In this case, the error can be ignored.\\\\nTo determine whether your device has a recovery environment configured, inspect the WinRE status by following these steps:\\\\n1. \\\\u200BOpen a Command Prompt window (cmd) as admin.\\\\n2. \\\\u200BTo check the WinRE status, run reagentc /info. If the WinRE is configured, a \\\\u0022Windows RE status\\\\u0022 field will appear in the output, with value \\\\u0022Enabled\\\\u0022. If WinRE is not configured, this field will have the value \\\\u0022Disabled\\\\u0022.\\\\n**Resolution**: Automatic resolution of this issue won\\\\u0027t be available in a future Windows update. Manual steps are necessary to complete the installation of this update on devices which are experiencing this error.\\\\nThe WinRE partition requires 250 megabytes of free space. Devices which do not have sufficient free space will need to increase the size of the partition via manual action. For guidance on making this change, review the following resources:\\\\n1. \\\\u200BA code script can be used to extend the partition size. A sample script has been provided in the documentation for adding an update package to WinRE. See [Extend the Windows RE Partition](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/manufacture/desktop/add-update-to-winre?view=windows-11#extend-the-windows-re-partition).\\\\n2. \\\\u200BGuidance to manually change the WinRE partition size can additionally be found in [KB5028997: Instructions to manually resize your partition to install the WinRE update](https://support.microsoft.com/help/5028997).\\\\nCompletion of these manual steps will allow the installation of this update to succeed.\\\\n**Affected platforms:**\\\",\\\"contentUrl\\\":\\\"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/release-health/resolved-issues-windows-11-21h2#issue-details\\\"},{\\\"title\\\":\\\"Add an update package to Windows RE\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Add an update package to Windows RE\\\\n## Extend the Windows RE Partition\\\\nThe sample script below can be used to increase the size of recovery partition to successfully update Windows Recovery Environment (WinRE). It is recommended to have 250MB of free space in the recovery partition for WinRE updates to install successfully. On devices that may not have adequate free space in the recovery partition, the sample script below can be used to extend the recovery partition by 250 MB.\\\\nReboot your machine before you run the script. This is critical as there may be pending partition operations staged on your machine that will need to be finalized before the script can safely increase the WinRE partition size. After your machine reboots open Powershell as admin and run **mkdir \\\\u003Cpath to new backup directory\\\\u003E** to create a backup directory that the script may use in case of failure to restore the original partition. Note the location of this backup directory as the script will ask for your backup path.If you are deploying this at scale, you can bypass the script prompting by using the parameters\\\\n**\\\\u0022\\\\u003Cscript file\\\\u003E -SkipConfirmation $true -BackupFolder \\\\u003Cfolder for backup\\\\u003E\\\\u0022**\\\\nFor example,\\\\n**Resize\\\\\\\\_script.ps1 -SkipConfirmation $true -BackupFolder c:\\\\\\\\winre\\\\\\\\_backup**\\\",\\\"contentUrl\\\":\\\"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/manufacture/desktop/add-update-to-winre?view=windows-11#extend-the-windows-re-partition\\\"},{\\\"title\\\":\\\"OEM Deployment of Windows 11 desktop editions\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# OEM Deployment of Windows 11 desktop editions\\\\n## Customize Windows with an answer file\\\\n\\\\u0060\\\\u0060\\\\u0060command\\\\n Dism /Get-TargetEditions /Image:C:\\\\\\\\mount\\\\\\\\windows\\\\n\\\\u0060\\\\u0060\\\\u0060\\\\n Note the edition IDs available.\\\\n5. Upgrade the edition to the Professional edition.\\\\n\\\\u0060\\\\u0060\\\\u0060command\\\\n Dism /Set-Edition:Professional /Image:C:\\\\\\\\mount\\\\\\\\windows\\\\n\\\\u0060\\\\u0060\\\\u0060\\\\n### Keep Windows settings through a recovery\\\\nIn recovery scenarios, Windows doesn\\\\u0027t automatically save settings created through with answer files, Windows Start Menu customizations created with LayoutModification.xml, or first-login info from oobe.xml.\\\\nTo make sure Windows saves your customizations:\\\\n1. Save copies of unattend.xml, LayoutModification.json, TaskbarLayoutModification.xml plus your C:\\\\\\\\mount\\\\\\\\windows\\\\\\\\Windows\\\\\\\\System32\\\\\\\\OOBE folder, in C:\\\\\\\\Recovery\\\\\\\\AutoApply\\\\\\\\.\\\\n### Optimize WinRE (part 1)\\\\n1. Increase the scratchspace size of the WinRE image.\\\\n\\\\u0060\\\\u0060\\\\u0060command\\\\n Dism /image:c:\\\\\\\\mount\\\\\\\\winre /set-scratchspace:512\\\\n\\\\u0060\\\\u0060\\\\u0060\\\\n2. Cleanup unused files and reduce the size of winre.wim\\\\n\\\\u0060\\\\u0060\\\\u0060command\\\\n dism /image:\\\\u0022c:\\\\\\\\mount\\\\\\\\winre\\\\u0022 /Cleanup-Image /StartComponentCleanup\\\\n\\\\u0060\\\\u0060\\\\u0060\\\\n### Unmount your images\\\\n1. Close all applications that might be accessing files from the image, including File Explorer.\\\\n2. Commit the changes and unmount the Windows RE image:\\\\n\\\\u0060\\\\u0060\\\\u0060command\\\\n Dism /Unmount-Image /MountDir:\\\\u0022C:\\\\\\\\mount\\\\\\\\winre\\\\u0022 /Commit\\\\n\\\\u0060\\\\u0060\\\\u0060\\\\n where C is the drive letter of the drive that contains the image.\\\\n This process can take a few minutes.\\\\n3. Make a backup copy of the updated Windows RE image and replace the old WinRE image with the newly exported one:\\\\n If prompted, specify \\\\u0060F\\\\u0060 for file\\\\n Troubleshoot: If you cannot see winre.wim under the specified directory, use the following command to set the file visible:\\\\n\\\\u0060\\\\u0060\\\\u0060command\\\\n attrib -h -a -s C:\\\\\\\\mount\\\\\\\\windows\\\\\\\\Windows\\\\\\\\System32\\\\\\\\Recovery\\\\\\\\winre.wim\\\\n\\\\u0060\\\\u0060\\\\u0060\\\\n4. Check the new size of the Windows RE image:\\\\n\\\\u0060\\\\u0060\\\\u0060command\\\\n Dir \\\\u0022C:\\\\\\\\mount\\\\\\\\windows\\\\\\\\Windows\\\\\\\\System32\\\\\\\\Recovery\\\\\\\\winre.wim\\\\u0022\\\\n\\\\u0060\\\\u0060\\\\u0060\\\\n5. Based on the size of the new winre.wim, adjust the partition sizes in the deployment scripts so they include enough room for winre.wim, as well as some additional free space.\\\",\\\"contentUrl\\\":\\\"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/manufacture/desktop/oem-deployment-of-windows-desktop-editions?view=windows-11#customize-windows-with-an-answer-file\\\"},{\\\"title\\\":\\\"OEM Deployment of Windows 11 desktop editions\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# OEM Deployment of Windows 11 desktop editions\\\\n## Customize Windows with an answer file\\\\n Follow the below partition layout size chart to determine the size of your recovery partition in the createpartitions-\\\\u003Cfirmware\\\\u003E-\\\\u003Cimageformat\\\\u003E.txt files. The amount of free space left is after you copy winre.wim to the hidden partition. See the below disk partition rules for more information.\\\\n | Partition Size | Free space |\\\\n | --- | --- |\\\\n | Less than 500 MB | Minimum 50 MB free |\\\\n | 450 MB - 680 MB | Minimum 320 MB free |\\\\n | More than 680 MB | 1024 MB free |\\\\n Example of the recovery partition size from the createpartitions diskpart scripts.:\\\\n\\\\u0060\\\\u0060\\\\u0060command\\\\n rem == 3. Windows RE tools partition ===============\\\\n create partition primary size=465\\\\n\\\\u0060\\\\u0060\\\\u0060\\\\n6. Optimize the Windows image the same way you did with the WinRE image:\\\\n\\\\u0060\\\\u0060\\\\u0060command\\\\n Dism /Image:c:\\\\\\\\mount\\\\\\\\windows /Cleanup-Image /StartComponentCleanup\\\\n\\\\u0060\\\\u0060\\\\u0060\\\\n7. Commit the changes and unmount the Windows image:\\\\n\\\\u0060\\\\u0060\\\\u0060command\\\\n Dism /Unmount-Image /MountDir:\\\\u0022C:\\\\\\\\mount\\\\\\\\windows\\\\u0022 /Commit\\\\n\\\\u0060\\\\u0060\\\\u0060\\\\n Where C is the drive letter of the drive that contains the image. This process may take several minutes.\\\\n8. Finish optimizing your image by exporting the image. During the export process, DISM removes files that were superseded and the image will have a reduced file size. Export the Windows image into a new image file:\\\\n\\\\u0060\\\\u0060\\\\u0060command\\\\n Dism /Export-Image /SourceImageFile:\\\\u0022C:\\\\\\\\temp\\\\\\\\lab\\\\\\\\Images\\\\\\\\basicimage.wim\\\\u0022 /SourceIndex:1 /DestinationImageFile:\\\\u0022C:\\\\\\\\temp\\\\\\\\lab\\\\\\\\Images\\\\\\\\install.wim\\\\u0022\\\\n\\\\u0060\\\\u0060\\\\u0060\\\\nYou now have a customized Windows image that you can deploy to other PCs. In the next section, we\\\\u0027ll show you how to deploy the image to your reference PC, make online changes, and then finalize the Windows image to get it ready for final deployment.\\\",\\\"contentUrl\\\":\\\"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/manufacture/desktop/oem-deployment-of-windows-desktop-editions?view=windows-11#customize-windows-with-an-answer-file\\\"},{\\\"title\\\":\\\"Windows Setup Command-Line Options\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Windows Setup Command-Line Options\\\\n## /ResizeRecoveryPartition\\\\nSpecifies whether it\\\\u0027s OK to resize the existing Windows Recovery Environment (Windows RE) partition or create a new one during installation.\\\\n**Syntax** /ResizeRecoveryPartition {Enable | Disable}\\\\n**Parameters**\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n| Parameter | Description| \\\\n|  --- | ---  |\\\\n| **Enable** | During installation, Windows can resize the existing Windows RE tools partition or create a new one if needed. |\\\\n| **Disable** | Windows does not resize the existing Windows RE tools partition or create a new one during installation. |\\\\n\\\\n**Examples**\\\\n\\\\u0060\\\\u0060\\\\u0060\\\\nsetup /resizerecoverypartition disable\\\\n\\\\u0060\\\\u0060\\\\u0060\\\\n**Applicability**\\\\n| Configuration | Applicable| \\\\n|  --- | ---  |\\\\n| Setup.exe started from [WinPE](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/manufacture/desktop/winpe-intro) | Yes |\\\\n| Setup.exe started from Windows 10 or above | Yes |\\\\n| [setupconfig.ini](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/manufacture/desktop/windows-setup-automation-overview) files used for feature updates | Yes |\\\\n\\\\n**Remarks** To learn more about Windows RE partitions, see [UEFI/GPT-based hard drive partitions](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/manufacture/desktop/configure-uefigpt-based-hard-drive-partitions?view=windows-11) and [BIOS/MBR-based hard drive partitions](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/manufacture/desktop/configure-biosmbr-based-hard-drive-partitions?view=windows-11).\\\",\\\"contentUrl\\\":\\\"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/manufacture/desktop/windows-setup-command-line-options?view=windows-11#resizerecoverypartition\\\"},{\\\"title\\\":\\\"Windows Recovery Environment (Windows RE)\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Windows Recovery Environment (Windows RE)\\\\n## Hard drive partitions\\\\nWhen you install Windows by using Windows Setup, WinRE is configured like this:\\\\n1. During Windows Setup, Windows prepares the hard drive partitions to support WinRE.\\\\n2. Windows initially places the WinRE image file (winre.wim) in the Windows partition, in the \\\\\\\\Windows\\\\\\\\System32\\\\\\\\Recovery folder.\\\\n Before delivering the PC to your customer, you can modify or replace the WinRE image file to include additional languages, drivers, or packages.\\\\n3. During the specialize configuration pass, the WinRE image file is copied into the recovery tools partition, so that the device can boot to the recovery tools even if there\\\\u0027s a problem with the Windows partition.\\\\nWhen you deploy Windows by applying images, you must manually configure the hard drive partitions. When WinRE is installed on a hard drive, the partition must be formatted as NTFS.\\\\nAdd the baseline WinRE tools image (winre.wim) to a separate partition from the Windows and data partitions. This enables your users to use WinRE even if the Windows partition is encrypted with Windows BitLocker Drive Encryption. It also prevents your users from accidentally modifying or removing the WinRE tools.\\\\nStore the recovery tools in a dedicated partition, directly after the Windows partition. This way, if future updates require a larger recovery partition, Windows will be able to handle it more efficiently by adjusting the Windows and recovery partition sizes, rather than having to create a new recovery partition size while the old one remains in place.\\\\nTo learn more, see [Configure UEFI/GPT-Based Hard Drive Partitions](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/manufacture/desktop/configure-uefigpt-based-hard-drive-partitions?view=windows-11) or [Configure BIOS/MBR-Based Hard Drive Partitions](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/manufacture/desktop/configure-biosmbr-based-hard-drive-partitions?view=windows-11).\\\\n## Memory requirements\\\\nIn order to boot Windows RE directly from memory (also known as RAM disk boot), a contiguous portion of physical memory (RAM) which can hold the entire Windows RE image (winre.wim) must be available. To optimize memory use, manufacturers should ensure that their firmware reserves memory locations either at the beginning or at the end of the physical memory address space.\\\",\\\"contentUrl\\\":\\\"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/manufacture/desktop/windows-recovery-environment--windows-re--technical-reference?view=windows-11#hard-drive-partitions\\\"},{\\\"title\\\":\\\"Bare metal reset/recovery: enable your users to create recovery media\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Bare metal reset/recovery: enable your users to create recovery media\\\\n## Creating configuration files\\\\n### Partition reset script\\\\n1. In Notepad, create a configuration file that partitions the hard drive after the hard drive has been reset. This script should be the same as the script used to create partitions on the hard drive, with the following exceptions:\\\\n1.1. The script should not contain commands to select or clean the drive. Windows identifies the system drive automatically. To learn more, see Identifying the System Drive later in this topic.\\\\n1.2. The script should assign letters to the system partition, the Windows partition, and the Windows RE tools partition.\\\\nNote\\\\nWhen using a custom partition layout the size of the Windows RE tools partition should have enough of free space to allow for a larger size in the future. Recommended size of the Windows RE tools partition is 990 MB with a minimum of 250 MB free.\\\\nExamples:\\\\nUEFI (based on [UEFI/GPT-based hard drive partitions](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/manufacture/desktop/configure-uefigpt-based-hard-drive-partitions?view=windows-11)):\\\\nBIOS (based on [BIOS/MBR-based hard drive partitions](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/manufacture/desktop/configure-biosmbr-based-hard-drive-partitions?view=windows-11)):\\\\n1. Save your file, for example, E:\\\\\\\\Recovery\\\\\\\\RecoveryImage\\\\\\\\ResetPartitions-UEFI.txt.\\\\n### Push-button reset configuration file (ResetConfig.xml)\\\\n1. In Notepad, create a configuration file that points to your push-button reset partition script.\\\\n For information about configuring this file, see [ResetConfig XML Reference](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/manufacture/desktop/resetconfig-xml-reference-s14?view=windows-11).\\\\nUEFI:\\\\nBIOS:\\\\n1. Save the file using the UTF-8 file format:\\\\n Click **File**, and then click **Save As**. In the **Encoding** box, select **UTF-8**, and save this file as E:\\\\\\\\Recovery\\\\\\\\RecoveryImage\\\\\\\\ResetConfig.xml.\\\",\\\"contentUrl\\\":\\\"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/manufacture/desktop/bare-metal-resetrecovery-enable-your-users-to-create-media-and-to-recover-hard-drive-space?view=windows-11#creating-configuration-files\\\"},{\\\"title\\\":\\\"Capture and apply Windows Full Flash Update (FFU) images\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Capture and apply Windows Full Flash Update (FFU) images\\\\n## Capturing and applying FFUs on differently-sized drives\\\\nIf you\\\\u0027ve optimized the FFU, DISM automatically resizes the Windows partition (or selected partition) to expand or shrink to fill the available space.\\\\nIf you don\\\\u0027t optimize the FFU, or if you\\\\u0027re deploying Windows 10, version 1809 or earlier, you\\\\u0027ll only be able to apply the FFU to drives that are the same size or larger than the original. You\\\\u0027ll also need to do some extra work to manage the recovery partition and partition sizes before and during deployment to make the best of use of space:\\\\n1. On the reference PC, install Windows with no recovery partition, and set up the Windows partition as the final partition on the drive. To set this up, use Windows Setup or a [deployment script](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/manufacture/desktop/oem-deployment-of-windows-desktop-editions-sample-scripts?view=windows-11\\\\u0026preserve-view=true\\\\u0026view=windows-10#apply-image).\\\\n2. Capture the FFU.\\\\n3. On the destination PC, deploy the FFU. For larger drives, there will be unused space at the end.\\\\n4. Using Diskpart, expand the Windows partition to fill the empty space.\\\\n Then, shrink the Windows partition to make room for the recovery partition.\\\\n Configure your recovery partition.\\\\n Example, using [Sample scripts: create recovery partition](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/manufacture/desktop/oem-deployment-of-windows-desktop-editions-sample-scripts?view=windows-11\\\\u0026preserve-view=true\\\\u0026view=windows-10#apply-recovery).\\\\n\\\\u0060\\\\u0060\\\\u0060cmd\\\\n ApplyRecovery.bat\\\\n\\\\u0060\\\\u0060\\\\u0060\\\",\\\"contentUrl\\\":\\\"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/manufacture/desktop/deploy-windows-using-full-flash-update--ffu?view=windows-11#capturing-and-applying-ffus-on-differently-sized-drives\\\"},{\\\"title\\\":\\\"Customize Windows RE\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Customize Windows RE\\\\n## Step 8: Optimizing the image, part 2 (optional)\\\\nIf you\\\\u0027ve optimized the image, you\\\\u0027ll need to export the image in order to see a change in the file size. During the export process, DISM removes files that were superseded.\\\\n1. Export the Windows RE image into a new Windows image file.\\\\n\\\\u0060\\\\u0060\\\\u0060cmd\\\\n Dism /Export-Image /SourceImageFile:c:\\\\\\\\mount\\\\\\\\windows\\\\\\\\windows\\\\\\\\system32\\\\\\\\recovery\\\\\\\\winre.wim /SourceIndex:1 /DestinationImageFile:c:\\\\\\\\mount\\\\\\\\winre-optimized.wim\\\\n\\\\u0060\\\\u0060\\\\u0060\\\\n2. Replace the old Windows RE image with the newly-optimized image.\\\\n\\\\u0060\\\\u0060\\\\u0060cmd\\\\n del c:\\\\\\\\mount\\\\\\\\windows\\\\\\\\windows\\\\\\\\system32\\\\\\\\recovery\\\\\\\\winre.wim\\\\n copy c:\\\\\\\\mount\\\\\\\\winre-optimized.wim c:\\\\\\\\mount\\\\\\\\windows\\\\\\\\windows\\\\\\\\system32\\\\\\\\recovery\\\\\\\\winre.wim\\\\n\\\\u0060\\\\u0060\\\\u0060\\\\n## Step 9: Unmount the Windows image\\\\nSave your changes back into the Windows base image.\\\\n1. Unmount the base Windows image:\\\\n\\\\u0060\\\\u0060\\\\u0060cmd\\\\n  Dism /Unmount-Image /MountDir:C:\\\\\\\\mount\\\\\\\\windows /Commit\\\\n\\\\u0060\\\\u0060\\\\u0060\\\",\\\"contentUrl\\\":\\\"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/manufacture/desktop/customize-windows-re?view=windows-11#step-8-optimizing-the-image,-part-2-optional\\\"},{\\\"title\\\":\\\"BIOS/MBR-based hard drive partitions\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# BIOS/MBR-based hard drive partitions\\\\n## Partition Requirements\\\\nHowever, if utility or data partitions are required, they should be placed either before the Windows partition or after the Windows RE partition. By keeping the Windows and recovery partitions together, then when future updates of Windows RE area available, Windows will be able to grow the Windows RE partition by shrinking the Windows partition.\\\\nThis layout makes it more difficult for end users to remove the data partition and merge the space with the Windows partition. For example, the Windows RE partition may need to be moved to the end of the unused space reclaimed from the data partition, so that the Windows partition can be extended. Windows 10 does not include functionality or utility to facilitate this process. However, manufacturers can develop and provide such a utility if PCs are shipped with data partitions.\\\\nEach partition can have a maximum of 2 terabytes (TB) of space.\\\\nIf you\\\\u0027re going to be adding more than four total partitions to the disk, see [Configure More than Four Partitions on a BIOS/MBR-Based Hard Disk](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/manufacture/desktop/configure-more-than-four-partitions-on-a-biosmbr-based-hard-disk?view=windows-11) for more info.\\\\n## Partition layout\\\\nIf you install Windows using a bootable USB key made by Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer (ICD), it creates the following layout by default: a system partition, a Windows partition, and a recovery tools partition.\\\\n## System and utility partitions\\\\nBy default, system partitions do not appear in File Explorer. This helps protect end users from accidentally modifying a partition.\\\\nTo keep system and utility partitions from being reset, use type 0x27. Do not use any of the following types: 0x7, 0x0c, 0x0b, 0x0e, 0x06, and 0x42.\\\\n### To set partitions as utility partitions\\\\nWhen you are using **Diskpart** in your deployment process use the \\\\u0060set id=27\\\\u0060 command after you create the partition.\\\\n### To verify that system and utility partitions exist\\\\n1. Click **Start**, right-click **This PC**, and then click **Manage**. The **Computer Management** window opens.\\\\n2. Click **Disk Management**. The list of available drives and partitions appears.\\\\n3. In the list of drives and partitions, confirm that the system and utility partitions are present and are not assigned a drive letter.\\\",\\\"contentUrl\\\":\\\"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/manufacture/desktop/configure-biosmbr-based-hard-drive-partitions?view=windows-11#partition-requirements\\\"}]}\"}],\"structuredContent\":{\"results\":[{\"title\":\"Resolved issues in Windows 11, version 21H2\",\"content\":\"# Resolved issues in Windows 11, version 21H2\\n## Issue details\\nDevices attempting to install the January 2024 Windows Recovery Environment update ([KB5034440](https://support.microsoft.com/help/5034440)) might display an error related to the size of the Recovery Environment's partition. The [Windows Recovery Environment (WinRE)](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/manufacture/desktop/windows-recovery-environment--windows-re--technical-reference?view=windows-11) is used to repair or recover from issues affecting Windows.\\nResulting from this error, the following message might be displayed.\\n1. ΓÇï\\\"0x80070643 - ERROR\\\\_INSTALL\\\\_FAILURE\\\"\\n**Important**: If your Windows device does not have a recovery environment configured, you do not need this update ([KB5034440](https://support.microsoft.com/help/5034440)). In this case, the error can be ignored.\\nTo determine whether your device has a recovery environment configured, inspect the WinRE status by following these steps:\\n1. ΓÇïOpen a Command Prompt window (cmd) as admin.\\n2. ΓÇïTo check the WinRE status, run reagentc /info. If the WinRE is configured, a \\\"Windows RE status\\\" field will appear in the output, with value \\\"Enabled\\\". If WinRE is not configured, this field will have the value \\\"Disabled\\\".\\n**Resolution**: Automatic resolution of this issue won't be available in a future Windows update. Manual steps are necessary to complete the installation of this update on devices which are experiencing this error.\\nThe WinRE partition requires 250 megabytes of free space. Devices which do not have sufficient free space will need to increase the size of the partition via manual action. For guidance on making this change, review the following resources:\\n1. ΓÇïA code script can be used to extend the partition size. A sample script has been provided in the documentation for adding an update package to WinRE. See [Extend the Windows RE Partition](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/manufacture/desktop/add-update-to-winre?view=windows-11#extend-the-windows-re-partition).\\n2. ΓÇïGuidance to manually change the WinRE partition size can additionally be found in [KB5028997: Instructions to manually resize your partition to install the WinRE update](https://support.microsoft.com/help/5028997).\\nCompletion of these manual steps will allow the installation of this update to succeed.\\n**Affected platforms:**\",\"contentUrl\":\"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/release-health/resolved-issues-windows-11-21h2#issue-details\"},{\"title\":\"Add an update package to Windows RE\",\"content\":\"# Add an update package to Windows RE\\n## Extend the Windows RE Partition\\nThe sample script below can be used to increase the size of recovery partition to successfully update Windows Recovery Environment (WinRE). It is recommended to have 250MB of free space in the recovery partition for WinRE updates to install successfully. On devices that may not have adequate free space in the recovery partition, the sample script below can be used to extend the recovery partition by 250 MB.\\nReboot your machine before you run the script. This is critical as there may be pending partition operations staged on your machine that will need to be finalized before the script can safely increase the WinRE partition size. After your machine reboots open Powershell as admin and run **mkdir <path to new backup directory>** to create a backup directory that the script may use in case of failure to restore the original partition. Note the location of this backup directory as the script will ask for your backup path.If you are deploying this at scale, you can bypass the script prompting by using the parameters\\n**\\\"<script file> -SkipConfirmation $true -BackupFolder <folder for backup>\\\"**\\nFor example,\\n**Resize\\\\_script.ps1 -SkipConfirmation $true -BackupFolder c:\\\\winre\\\\_backup**\",\"contentUrl\":\"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/manufacture/desktop/add-update-to-winre?view=windows-11#extend-the-windows-re-partition\"},{\"title\":\"OEM Deployment of Windows 11 desktop editions\",\"content\":\"# OEM Deployment of Windows 11 desktop editions\\n## Customize Windows with an answer file\\n```command\\n Dism /Get-TargetEditions /Image:C:\\\\mount\\\\windows\\n```\\n Note the edition IDs available.\\n5. Upgrade the edition to the Professional edition.\\n```command\\n Dism /Set-Edition:Professional /Image:C:\\\\mount\\\\windows\\n```\\n### Keep Windows settings through a recovery\\nIn recovery scenarios, Windows doesn't automatically save settings created through with answer files, Windows Start Menu customizations created with LayoutModification.xml, or first-login info from oobe.xml.\\nTo make sure Windows saves your customizations:\\n1. Save copies of unattend.xml, LayoutModification.json, TaskbarLayoutModification.xml plus your C:\\\\mount\\\\windows\\\\Windows\\\\System32\\\\OOBE folder, in C:\\\\Recovery\\\\AutoApply\\\\.\\n### Optimize WinRE (part 1)\\n1. Increase the scratchspace size of the WinRE image.\\n```command\\n Dism /image:c:\\\\mount\\\\winre /set-scratchspace:512\\n```\\n2. Cleanup unused files and reduce the size of winre.wim\\n```command\\n dism /image:\\\"c:\\\\mount\\\\winre\\\" /Cleanup-Image /StartComponentCleanup\\n```\\n### Unmount your images\\n1. Close all applications that might be accessing files from the image, including File Explorer.\\n2. Commit the changes and unmount the Windows RE image:\\n```command\\n Dism /Unmount-Image /MountDir:\\\"C:\\\\mount\\\\winre\\\" /Commit\\n```\\n where C is the drive letter of the drive that contains the image.\\n This process can take a few minutes.\\n3. Make a backup copy of the updated Windows RE image and replace the old WinRE image with the newly exported one:\\n If prompted, specify `F` for file\\n Troubleshoot: If you cannot see winre.wim under the specified directory, use the following command to set the file visible:\\n```command\\n attrib -h -a -s C:\\\\mount\\\\windows\\\\Windows\\\\System32\\\\Recovery\\\\winre.wim\\n```\\n4. Check the new size of the Windows RE image:\\n```command\\n Dir \\\"C:\\\\mount\\\\windows\\\\Windows\\\\System32\\\\Recovery\\\\winre.wim\\\"\\n```\\n5. Based on the size of the new winre.wim, adjust the partition sizes in the deployment scripts so they include enough room for winre.wim, as well as some additional free space.\",\"contentUrl\":\"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/manufacture/desktop/oem-deployment-of-windows-desktop-editions?view=windows-11#customize-windows-with-an-answer-file\"},{\"title\":\"OEM Deployment of Windows 11 desktop editions\",\"content\":\"# OEM Deployment of Windows 11 desktop editions\\n## Customize Windows with an answer file\\n Follow the below partition layout size chart to determine the size of your recovery partition in the createpartitions-<firmware>-<imageformat>.txt files. Windows RE tools partition ===============\\n create partition primary size=465\\n```\\n6. It also prevents your users from accidentally modifying or removing the WinRE tools.\\nStore the recovery tools in a dedicated partition, directly after the Windows partition. This way, if future updates require a larger recovery partition, Windows will be able to handle it more efficiently by adjusting the Windows and recovery partition sizes, rather than having to create a new recovery partition size while the old one remains in place.\\nTo learn more, see [Configure UEFI/GPT-Based Hard Drive Partitions](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/manufacture/desktop/configure-uefigpt-based-hard-drive-partitions?view=windows-11) or [Configure BIOS/MBR-Based Hard Drive Partitions](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/manufacture/desktop/configure-biosmbr-based-hard-drive-partitions?view=windows-11).\\n## Memory requirements\\nIn order to boot Windows RE directly from memory (also known as RAM disk boot), a contiguous portion of physical memory (RAM) which can hold the entire Windows RE image (winre.wim) must be available. To optimize memory use, manufacturers should ensure that their firmware reserves memory locations either at the beginning or at the end of the physical memory address space.\",\"contentUrl\":\"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/manufacture/desktop/windows-recovery-environment--windows-re--technical-reference?view=windows-11#hard-drive-partitions\"},{\"title\":\"Bare metal reset/recovery: enable your users to create recovery media\",\"content\":\"# Bare metal reset/recovery: enable your users to create recovery media\\n## Creating configuration files\\n### Partition reset script\\n1. In Notepad, create a configuration file that partitions the hard drive after the hard drive has been reset. This script should be the same as the script used to create partitions on the hard drive, with the following exceptions:\\n1.1. The script should not contain commands to select or clean the drive. Windows identifies the system drive automatically. To learn more, see Identifying the System Drive later in this topic.\\n1.2. The script should assign letters to the system partition, the Windows partition, and the Windows RE tools partition.\\nNote\\nWhen using a custom partition layout the size of the Windows RE tools partition should have enough of free space to allow for a larger size in the future. Recommended size of the Windows RE tools partition is 990 MB with a minimum of 250 MB free.\\nExamples:\\nUEFI (based on [UEFI/GPT-based hard drive partitions](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/manufacture/desktop/configure-uefigpt-based-hard-drive-partitions?view=windows-11)):\\nBIOS (based on [BIOS/MBR-based hard drive partitions](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/manufacture/desktop/configure-biosmbr-based-hard-drive-partitions?view=windows-11)):\\n1. Save your file, for example, E:\\\\Recovery\\\\RecoveryImage\\\\ResetPartitions-UEFI.txt.\\n### Push-button reset configuration file (ResetConfig.xml)\\n1. In Notepad, create a configuration file that points to your push-button reset partition script.\\n For information about configuring this file, see [ResetConfig XML Reference](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/manufacture/desktop/resetconfig-xml-reference-s14?view=windows-11).\\nUEFI:\\nBIOS:\\n1. Save the file using the UTF-8 file format:\\n Click **File**, and then click **Save As**. In the **Encoding** box, select **UTF-8**, and save this file as E:\\\\Recovery\\\\RecoveryImage\\\\ResetConfig.xml.\",\"contentUrl\":\"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/manufacture/desktop/bare-metal-resetrecovery-enable-your-users-to-create-media-and-to-recover-hard-drive-space?view=windows-11#creating-configuration-files\"},{\"title\":\"Capture and apply Windows Full Flash Update (FFU) images\",\"content\":\"# Capture and apply Windows Full Flash Update (FFU) images\\n## Capturing and applying FFUs on differently-sized drives\\nIf you've optimized the FFU, DISM automatically resizes the Windows partition (or selected partition) to expand or shrink to fill the available space.\\nIf you don't optimize the FFU, or if you're deploying Windows 10, version 1809 or earlier, you'll only be able to apply the FFU to drives that are the same size or larger than the original. You'll also need to do some extra work to manage the recovery partition and partition sizes before and during deployment to make the best of use of space:\\n1. On the reference PC, install Windows with no recovery partition, and set up the Windows partition as the final partition on the drive. To set this up, use Windows Setup or a [deployment script](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/manufacture/desktop/oem-deployment-of-windows-desktop-editions-sample-scripts?view=windows-11&preserve-view=true&view=windows-10#apply-image).\\n2. Capture the FFU.\\n3. On the destination PC, deploy the FFU. For larger drives, there will be unused space at the end.\\n4. Using Diskpart, expand the Windows partition to fill the empty space.\\n Then, shrink the Windows partition to make room for the recovery partition.\\n Configure your recovery partition.\\n Example, using [Sample scripts: create recovery partition](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/manufacture/desktop/oem-deployment-of-windows-desktop-editions-sample-scripts?view=windows-11&preserve-view=true&view=windows-10#apply-recovery).\\n```cmd\\n ApplyRecovery.bat\\n```\",\"contentUrl\":\"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/manufacture/desktop/deploy-windows-using-full-flash-update--ffu?view=windows-11#capturing-and-applying-ffus-on-differently-sized-drives\"},{\"title\":\"Customize Windows RE\",\"content\":\"# Customize Windows RE\\n## Step 8: Optimizing the image, part 2 (optional)\\nIf you've optimized the image, you'll need to export the image in order to see a change in the file size. During the export process, DISM removes files that were superseded.\\n1. Export the Windows RE image into a new Windows image file.\\n```cmd\\n Dism /Export-Image /SourceImageFile:c:\\\\mount\\\\windows\\\\windows\\\\system32\\\\recovery\\\\winre.wim /SourceIndex:1 /DestinationImageFile:c:\\\\mount\\\\winre-optimized.wim\\n```\\n2. Replace the old Windows RE image with the newly-optimized image.\\n```cmd\\n del c:\\\\mount\\\\windows\\\\windows\\\\system32\\\\recovery\\\\winre.wim\\n copy c:\\\\mount\\\\winre-optimized.wim c:\\\\mount\\\\windows\\\\windows\\\\system32\\\\recovery\\\\winre.wim\\n```\\n## Step 9: Unmount the Windows image\\nSave your changes back into the Windows base image.\\n1. Unmount the base Windows image:\\n```cmd\\n  Dism /Unmount-Image /MountDir:C:\\\\mount\\\\windows /Commit\\n```\",\"contentUrl\":\"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/manufacture/desktop/customize-windows-re?view=windows-11#step-8-optimizing-the-image,-part-2-optional\"},{\"title\":\"BIOS/MBR-based hard drive partitions\",\"content\":\"# BIOS/MBR-based hard drive partitions\\n## Partition Requirements\\nHowever, if utility or data partitions are required, they should be placed either before the Windows partition or after the Windows RE partition. By keeping the Windows and recovery partitions together, then when future updates of Windows RE area available, Windows will be able to grow the Windows RE partition by shrinking the Windows partition.\\nThis layout makes it more difficult for end users to remove the data partition and merge the space with the Windows partition. For example, the Windows RE partition may need to be moved to the end of the unused space reclaimed from the data partition, so that the Windows partition can be extended. Windows 10 does not include functionality or utility to facilitate this process. However, manufacturers can develop and provide such a utility if PCs are shipped with data partitions.\\nEach partition can have a maximum of 2 terabytes (TB) of space.\\nIf you're going to be adding more than four total partitions to the disk, see [Configure More than Four Partitions on a BIOS/MBR-Based Hard Disk](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/manufacture/desktop/configure-more-than-four-partitions-on-a-biosmbr-based-hard-disk?view=windows-11) for more info.\\n## Partition layout\\nIf you install Windows using a bootable USB key made by Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer (ICD), it creates the following layout by default: a system partition, a Windows partition, and a recovery tools partition.\\n## System and utility partitions\\nBy default, system partitions do not appear in File Explorer. This helps protect end users from accidentally modifying a partition.\\nTo keep system and utility partitions from being reset, use type 0x27. Do not use any of the following types: 0x7, 0x0c, 0x0b, 0x0e, 0x06, and 0x42.\\n### To set partitions as utility partitions\\nWhen you are using **Diskpart** in your deployment process use the `set id=27` command after you create the partition.\\n### To verify that system and utility partitions exist\\n1. Click **Start**, right-click **This PC**, and then click **Manage**. The **Computer Management** window opens.\\n2. Click **Disk Management**. The list of available drives and partitions appears.\\n3. In the list of drives and partitions, confirm that the system and utility partitions are present and are not assigned a drive letter.\",\"contentUrl\":\"https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/manufacture/desktop/configure-biosmbr-based-hard-drive-partitions?view=windows-11#partition-requirements\"}]}}"}

thinking.text: GPU inference works. Now I need to set up the HF token for the MCP server. The user needs to get a token from Hugging Face and set it as an environment variable.
Found it! The docs say to go to Cursor Settings > Models and enter API keys there. Let me search for the OpenAI Base URL override specifically.
Good, uv is installed. Now I need to refresh PATH and create a virtual environment with PyTorch CUDA support.
