running this script to ensure any pending partition actions are finalized\\\")\\r\\nLogMessage(\\\"\\\")\\r\\nif ($SkipConfirmation)\\r\\n{\\r\\n  LogMessage(\\\"User chose to skip confirmation\\\")\\r\\n  LogMessage(\\\"Proceeding with changes...\\\")\\r\\n}\\r\\nelse\\r\\n{\\r\\n  $userInput = Read-Host -Prompt \\\"Would you like to proceed? Y for Yes and N for No\\\"\\r\\n    \\r\\n  if ($userInput -ieq \\\"Y\\\")\\r\\n  {\\r\\n    LogMessage(\\\"Proceeding with changes...\\\")\\r\\n  }\\r\\n  elseif ($userInput -ieq \\\"N\\\")\\r\\n  {\\r\\n    LogMessage(\\\"Canceling based on user request, no changes were made to the system\\\")\\r\\n    exit 0\\r\\n  }\\r\\n  else\\r\\n  {\\r\\n    LogMessage(\\\"Error: Unexpected user input: [\\\" + $userInput + \\\"]\\\") \\r\\n    exit 0\\r\\n  }\\r\\n}\\r\\nLogMessage(\\\"\\\")\\r\\nLogMessage(\\\"Note: To prevent unexpected results, please do not interrupt the execution or restart your system\\\")\\r\\n# ------------------------------------\\r\\n# Do the actual execution\\r\\n# The main flow is:\\r\\n# 1. Check whether ReAgent.xml has stage location and clear it for repartiion\\r\\n# 2. Disable WinRE as WinRE partition will be deleted\\r\\n# 3. Perform the repartition to create a larger WinRE partition\\r\\n# 4. Re-enable WinRE\\r\\n# ------------------------------------\\r\\nLogMessage(\\\"\\\")\\r\\n# Load ReAgent.xml to clear Stage location\\r\\nLogMessage(\\\"Loading [\\\" + $ReAgentXmlPath + \\\"] ...\\\")\\r\\n$xml = [xml](Get-Content -Path $ReAgentXmlPath)\\r\\n$node = $xml.WindowsRE.ImageLocation\\r\\nif (($node.path -eq \\\"\\\") -And ($node.guid -eq \\\"{00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000}\\\") -And ($node.offset -eq \\\"0\\\") -And ($node.id -eq \\\"0\\\"))\\r\\n{\\r\\n  LogMessage(\\\"Stage location info is empty\\\")\\r\\n}\\r\\nelse\\r\\n{\\r\\n  LogMessage(\\\"Clearing stage location info...\\\")\\r\\n  $node.path = \\\"\\\"\\r\\n  $node.offset = \\\"0\\\"\\r\\n  $node.guid= \\\"{00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000}\\\"\\r\\n  $node.id=\\\"0\\\"\\r\\n  # Save the change\\r\\n  LogMessage(\\\"Saving changes to [\\\" + $ReAgentXmlPath + \\\"]...\\\")\\r\\n  $xml.Save($ReAgentXmlPath)\\r\\n}\\r\\n# Disable WinRE\\r\\nLogMessage(\\\"Disabling WinRE...\\\")\\r\\nreagentc /disable\\r\\nif (!($LASTEXITCODE -eq 0))\\r\\n{\\r\\n  LogMessage(\\\"Warning: encountered an error when disabling WinRE: \\\" + $LASTEXITCODE)\\r\\n  exit $LASTEXITCODE\\r\\n}\\r\\n# Verify WinRE is under C:\\\\Windows\\\\System32\\\\Recovery\\\\WinRE.wim\\r\\n$disableWinREPath = Join-Path -Path $system32Path -ChildPath \\\"\\\\Recovery\\\\WinRE.wim\\\"\\r\\nLogMessage(\\\"Verifying that WinRE wim exists in downlevel at default location\\\")\\r\\nif (!(Test-Path $disableWinREPath))\\r\\n{\\r\\n  LogMessage(\\\"Error: Cannot find \\\" + $disableWinREPath)\\r\\n  \\r\\n  # Re-enable WinRE\\r\\n  LogMessage(\\\"Re-enabling WinRE on error...\\\")\\r\\n  reagentc /enable\\r\\n  if (!($LASTEXITCODE -eq 0))\\r\\n  {\\r\\n    LogMessage(\\\"Warning: encountered an error when enabling WinRE: \\\" + $LASTEXITCODE)\\r\\n  }\\r\\n  exit 1\\r\\n}\\r\\n# ------------------------------------\\r\\n# Perform the repartition\\r\\n# 1. Resize the OS partition\\r\\n# 2. Delete the WinRE partition\\r\\n# 3. Create a new WinRE partition\\r\\n# ------------------------------------\\r\\nLogMessage(\\\"Performing repartition to extend the WinRE partition ...\\\")\\r\\n# 1. Resize the OS partition\\r\\nif ($NeedShrink)\\r\\n{\\r\\n  LogMessage(\\\"Shrinking the OS partition to create a larger WinRE partition\\\")\\r\\n  LogMessage(\\\"Resizing the OS partition to: [\\\" + $targetOSPartitionSize + \\\"]...\\\")\\r\\n  Resize-Partition -DriveLetter $OSDrive -Size $targetOSPartitionSize\\r\\n  if ($Error.Count -gt 0) {\\r\\n    LogMessage(\\\"Error: Resize-Partition encountered errors: \\\" + $Error[0].Exception.Message)\\r\\n    \\r\\n    # Re-enable WinRE\\r\\n    LogMessage(\\\"Re-enabling WinRE on error...\\\")\\r\\n    reagentc /enable\\r\\n    if (!($LASTEXITCODE -eq 0))\\r\\n    {\\r\\n      LogMessage(\\\"Warning: encountered an error when enabling WinRE: \\\" + $LASTEXITCODE)\\r\\n    }\\r\\n    exit 1\\r\\n  }\\r\\n  $OSPartitionAfterShrink = Get-Partition -DriveLetter $OSDrive\\r\\n  LogMessage(\\\"Target partition size: \\\" + $targetOSPartitionSize)\\r\\n  LogMessage(\\\"Size of OS partition after shrinking: \\\" + $OSPartitionAfterShrink.Size)\\r\\n}\\r\\n# 2. Delete the WinRE partition\\r\\nLogMessage(\\\"\\\")\\r\\nif ($WinREIsOnSystemPartition)\\r\\n{\\r\\n  LogMessage(\\\"Existing WinRE partition is System partition, skipping deletion\\\")\\r\\n}\\r\\nelse\\r\\n{  \\r\\n  # If requested by user, backup rest of the content on WinRE partition to backup directory\\r\\n  if ($Needbackup)\\r\\n  {\\r\\n    $sourcePath = $WinREPartition.AccessPaths[0] \\r\\n    LogMessage(\\\"Copying content on WinRE partition from [\\\" + $sourcePath + \\\"] to [\\\" + $BackupFolder + \\\"]...\\\")\\r\\n    \\r\\n    # Copy-Item may have access issue with certain system folders, enumerate the children items and exlcude them\\r\\n    $items = Get-ChildItem -LiteralPath $sourcePath -Force\\r\\n    foreach ($item in $items)\\r\\n    {\\r\\n      if ($item.Name -ieq \\\"System Volume Information\\\")\\r\\n      {\\r\\n        continue\\r\\n      }\\r\\n      $sourceItemPath = Join-Path -Path $sourcePath -ChildPath $item.Name\\r\\n      $destItemPath = Join-Path -Path $BackupFolder -ChildPath $item.Name\\r\\n      try \\r\\n      {\\r\\n        LogMessage(\\\"Copying [\\\" + $sourceItemPath + \\\"] to [\\\" + $destItemPath + \\\"]...\\\")\\r\\n        Copy-Item -LiteralPath $sourceItemPath -Destination $destItemPath -Recurse -Force\\r\\n      } catch \\r\\n      {\\r\\n        LogMessage(\\\"Error: An error occurred during copy: $_\\\")\\r\\n        exit 1\\r\\n      }\\r\\n    }\\r\\n    \\r\\n    LogMessage(\\\"Backup completed\\\")\\r\\n    LogMessage(\\\"\\\")\\r\\n  }\\r\\n  LogMessage(\\\"Deleting WinRE partition: Disk [\\\" + $OSDiskIndex + \\\"] Partition [\\\" + $WinREPartitionIndex + \\\"]...\\\")\\r\\n  Remove-Partition -DiskNumber $OSDiskIndex -PartitionNumber $WinREPartitionIndex -Confirm:$false\\r\\n  if ($Error.Count -gt 0) {\\r\\n    LogMessage(\\\"Error: Remove-Partition encountered errors: \\\" + $Error[0].Exception.Message)\\r\\n    exit 1\\r\\n  }\\r\\n}\\r\\n# A short sleep for the partition change\\r\\nSleep 5\\r\\n# 3. Create a new WinRE partition\\r\\nLogMessage(\\\"\\\")\\r\\nLogMessage(\\\"Creating new WinRE partition...\\\")\\r\\nLogMessage(\\\"Target size: \\\" + $targetWinREPartitionSize)\\r\\nif ($diskType -ieq \\\"GPT\\\")\\r\\n{\\r\\n  $partition = New-Partition -DiskNumber $OSDiskIndex -Size $targetWinREPartitionSize -GptType \\\"{de94bba4-06d1-4d40-a16a-bfd50179d6ac}\\\"\\r\\n  \\r\\n  $newPartitionIndex = $partition.PartitionNumber\\r\\n  # A short sleep to make sure the partition is ready for formatting\\r\\n  Sleep 2\\r\\n  LogMessage(\\\"Formating the partition...\\\")\\r\\n  $result = Format-Volume -Partition $partition -FileSystem NTFS -Confirm:$false\\r\\n  if ($Error.Count -gt 0) {\\r\\n    LogMessage(\\\"Error: Format-Volume encountered errors: \\\" + $Error[0].Exception.Message)\\r\\n    exit 1\\r\\n  }\\r\\n}\\r\\nelse\\r\\n{\\r\\n  #$partition = New-Partition -DiskNumber $OSDiskIndex -Size $targetWinREPartitionSize -MbrType 0x27\\r\\n id=27\\r\\nformat quick fs=ntfs label=\\\"Recovery\\\"\\r\\nset id=27\\r\\n\\\"@\\r\\n  $TempPath = $env:Temp\\r\\n  $diskpartSciptFile = Join-Path -Path $TempPath -ChildPath \\\"\\\\ExtendWinRE_MBR_PowershellScript.txt\\\"\\r\\n  \\r\\n  LogMessage(\\\"Creating temporary diskpart script to create Recovery partition on MBR disk...\\\")\\r\\n  LogMessage(\\\"Temporary diskpart script file: \\\" + $diskpartSciptFile)\\r\\n  $diskpartScript | Out-File -FilePath $diskpartSciptFile -Encoding ascii\\r\\n  \\r\\n  LogMessage(\\\"Executing diskpart script...\\\")\\r\\n  try \\r\\n  {\\r\\n    $diskpartOutput = diskpart /s $diskpartSciptFile\\r\\n    \\r\\n    if ($diskpartOutput -match \\\"DiskPart successfully\\\") \\r\\n    {\\r\\n      LogMessage(\\\"Diskpart script executed successfully\\\")\\r\\n    }\\r\\n    else\\r\\n    {\\r\\n      LogMessage(\\\"Error executing diskpart script:\\\" + $diskpartOutput)\\r\\n      exit 1\\r\\n    }\\r\\n    LogMessage(\\\"Deleting temporary diskpart script file...\\\")\\r\\n    Remove-Item $diskpartSciptFile\\r\\n  }\\r\\n  catch \\r\\n  {\\r\\n    LogMessage(\\\"Error executing diskpart script: $_\\\")\\r\\n    exit 1\\r\\n  }\\r\\n  \\r\\n  $vol = Get-Volume -FileSystemLabel \\\"Recovery\\\"\\r\\n  $newPartitionIndex = (Get-Partition | Where-Object { $_.AccessPaths -contains $vol.Path } ).PartitionNumber\\r\\n}\\r\\nif ($Error.Count -gt 0) \\r\\n{\\r\\n  LogMessage(\\\"Error: New-Partition encountered errors: \\\" + $Error[0].Exception.Message)\\r\\n  exit codeBlocks.content:
# AGENT ONBOARDING - READ FIRST

**STOP. Before generating any code, read this file completely.**

This workspace uses pre-built helper scripts and templates to minimize token consumption and maximize code quality. Do NOT generate multi-step shell/git commands manually. Use the scripts below.

---

## Critical Rules

1. **No emojis** in source code, configs, or documentation
2. **Default languages**: PowerShell (Windows), POSIX sh (Unix), C17, AMD64/ARM64 assembly
3. **Universal config paradigm**: One `.cfg` file consumed by three scripts (POSIX sh, PowerShell v5, PowerShell v7)
4. **Use existing scripts** instead of generating equivalent commands
5. **BSD-2-Clause** license with DCO sign-off required
6. **Check BROKEN_SCRIPTS.md** for scripts that need verification before use

---

## CRITICAL: NEVER DELEGATE WORK TO THE USER

**THIS IS NON-NEGOTIABLE. READ CAREFULLY.**

Agents exist to DO THE WORK. The user is NOT your assistant. You are THEIR assistant.

- NEVER ask the user to run commands for you
- NEVER ask the user to copy-paste output
- NEVER ask the user to check something manually
- NEVER say "please run this in your terminal"
- USE the native shell tool directly (shell bug resolved 2025-12-14)

If you cannot complete a task, explain WHY and propose an AUTOMATED solution. Do NOT make the user do your job.

---

## GENERAL Scripts, SPECIFIC Tasks

**CRITICAL CONCEPT:** The scripts in this workspace are GENERAL-PURPOSE building blocks, NOT task-specific solutions.

Agents must understand:

1. **Scripts are composable** - Combine multiple general scripts to accomplish specific tasks
2. **Templates are parameterized** - One template serves many use cases via `.cfg` substitution
3. **No script-per-task assumption** - Do NOT expect `do-exactly-what-I-need.ps1` to exist
4. **Adapt and compose** - Use existing scripts creatively; extend only when necessary

**Example - Creating a New C Project:**
```powershell
# WRONG: Looking for "New-CProject.ps1"
# RIGHT: Compose general tools
.\New-Project-v7.ps1 -ConfigFile project.cfg  # General scaffolding
.\Invoke-Template.ps1 -Language c             # Language-specific templates
.\git-ops\New-Repo.ps1 -WithBackup            # Git setup
```

---

## Fravia Search Strategy + Suckless Principles

Apply reverse-engineering search methodology with minimal-complexity execution.

### Fravia Method: Search Strategy Formulation

Before searching, PLAN the search:

1. **Define the target** - What exactly are you looking for? (file, function, pattern, concept)
2. **Predict locations** - Where would this logically exist? (directory, file type, naming convention)
3. **Choose search depth** - Broad reconnaissance first, then targeted drilling
4. **Formulate patterns** - Build regex from known fragments, not guesses
5. **Cross-reference results** - Validate findings against multiple indicators

### Suckless Principles: Minimal Complexity, Maximum Effect

**AVOID** these anti-patterns (Useless Use of Cat and friends):

```sh
# BAD: UUoC - Useless Use of Cat
cat file.txt | grep pattern
cat file.txt | wc -l
cat file.txt | awk '{print $1}'
cat file.txt | sed 's/foo/bar/'

# GOOD: Direct invocation
grep pattern file.txt
wc -l < file.txt
awk '{print $1}' file.txt
sed 's/foo/bar/' file.txt
```

**AVOID** unnecessary tool chains:

```sh
# BAD: Multi-tool chain for simple task
cat file | grep foo | sed 's/bar/baz/' | awk '{print $2}' | wc -l

# GOOD: Single tool when possible
awk '/foo/ { gsub(/bar/, "baz"); print $2; count++ } END { print count }' file
```

**PREFER** heredoc and ed/vi for edits:

```sh
# BAD: Multiple sed invocations
sed -i 's/old1/new1/' file
sed -i 's/old2/new2/' file
sed -i 's/old3/new3/' file

# GOOD: Single heredoc with ed
ed -s file <<'EOF'
%s/old1/new1/g
%s/old2/new2/g
%s/old3/new3/g
w
q
EOF

# GOOD: Single sed with multiple expressions
sed -i -e 's/old1/new1/g' -e 's/old2/new2/g' -e 's/old3/new3/g' file
```

### Search Tool Priority

Use tools in this order (most efficient first):

| Priority | Tool | Use Case |
|----------|------|----------|
| 1 | `grep -r` / `rg` | Known pattern, broad search |
| 2 | `find` + `-name` | Known filename pattern |
| 3 | `git grep` | Within git repo, respects .gitignore |
| 4 | Codebase semantic search | Concept/meaning-based queries |
| 5 | Web search | External documentation, APIs |

### PowerShell Equivalents

```powershell
# BAD: Pipeline abuse
Get-Content file.txt | Select-String pattern
Get-Content file.txt | Measure-Object -Line
Get-Content file.txt | ForEach-Object { $_.Split()[0] }

# GOOD: Direct parameter usage
Select-String -Path file.txt -Pattern pattern
(Get-Content file.txt).Count
(Get-Content file.txt) -replace 'pattern', 'replacement'

# GOOD: Single expression for complex operations
Get-Content file.txt | ForEach-Object -Begin { $count = 0 } -Process {
    if ($_ -match 'pattern') { $count++ }
} -End { $count }
```

### The Suckless Test

Before executing a command chain, ask:

1. Can this be done with ONE tool instead of many?
2. Am I piping cat/Get-Content unnecessarily?
3. Would a heredoc/here-string be cleaner?
4. Is there a built-in flag that eliminates a pipeline stage?
5. Am I using awk/sed when grep alone suffices (or vice versa)?

**Rule of thumb:** If your command has more than 2 pipes, reconsider the approach.

---

## RESOLVED: Agent Shell Bug Workaround (Windows 11)

**Status:** RESOLVED as of 2025-12-14. Shell tool now works correctly.

**History:** Between 2025-12-07 and 2025-12-14, Cursor Shell tool returned `pid: -1` on Windows 11 (build 26200, Cursor 2.1.50+). This has been fixed.

### File-Based Shell Bridge (Archived - For Reference Only)

The bridge workaround below is no longer needed but preserved for reference if the issue recurs.

<details>
<summary>Click to expand archived workaround</summary>

When the Cursor Shell tool fails, use `agent-shell-bridge.ps1` which runs in the user's manual terminal.

**To execute shell commands:**

1. Write command to `.agent-command.txt` using the Write tool
2. Wait briefly, then read `.agent-status.txt` (should say `DONE`)
3. Read result from `.agent-result.txt`

**Example:**

```
# Step 1: Write command
Write tool -> .agent-command.txt -> "hostname; Get-Date"

# Step 2: Check status
Read tool -> .agent-status.txt -> "DONE"

# Step 3: Read result
Read tool -> .agent-result.txt -> "EXIT_CODE=0\nDESKTOP-7KTB236\n..."
```

**Files:**

| File | Purpose |
|------|---------|
| `.agent-command.txt` | Write your command here (bridge consumes it) |
| `.agent-status.txt` | READY/RUNNING/DONE |
| `.agent-result.txt` | EXIT_CODE=N followed by output |
| `agent-shell-bridge.ps1` | The bridge script (user starts once) |

</details>

---

---

## Known Issues: BROKEN_SCRIPTS.md

Before using or modifying scripts, check `BROKEN_SCRIPTS.md` for:

- Scripts that silently skip critical functionality
- Useless Use of Cat (UUoC) patterns in shell scripts
- Placeholder values that should be complete functions
- Templates with unsubstituted variables
- Scripts requiring verification

**When a script fails during agent operations:**
1. Do NOT attempt to fix inline
2. Add to `BROKEN_SCRIPTS.md` with filename, filepath, and issue description
3. Mark as unchecked `[ ]`
4. Only check off `[x]` when fully verified working

---

## Helper Script Index

All scripts are in `github-backup/cursor-project-scaffolding-backup/ludoplex-cursor-project-scaffolding-backup-*/`

### Project Scaffolding

| Task | Script | Config |
|------|--------|--------|
| Create new project | `new-project.sh` / `New-Project-v5.ps1` / `New-Project-v7.ps1` | `project.cfg` |
| Watch/backup files | `watch-project.sh` / `Watch-Project-v5.ps1` / `Watch-Project-v7.ps1` | `watcher.cfg` |
| Process templates | `Invoke-Template.ps1` | (inline params) |

### Git Operations (git-ops/)

| Task | Script |
|------|--------|
| Create GitHub repo | `New-Repo.ps1` / `new-repo.sh` |
| Clone with backup | `Import-Repo.ps1` / `import-repo.sh` (legacy) |

### Import Repository (github-backup/) - with gh fallback

| Task | Script | Config |
|------|--------|--------|
| Import repo | `import-repo.sh` / `Import-Repo-v5.ps1` / `Import-Repo-v7.ps1` | `import-repo.cfg` |

Tries git clone first, falls back to gh api zip download when git fails.
| Create branch | `New-Branch.ps1` / `new-branch.sh` |
| Archive project | `Archive-Repo.ps1` / `archive-repo.sh` |
| Sync backups | `Sync-Backup.ps1` / `sync-backup.sh` |
| Update index | `Update-RepoIndex.ps1` / `update-index.sh` |

### Utilities (utils/)

| Task | Script |
|------|--------|
| Project tree | `Get-ProjectStructure.ps1` |
| Find files | `Search-Files.ps1` / `search-files.sh` |
| Search content | `Search-Content.ps1` / `search-content.sh` |

### Production Readiness (prr/)

| Task | Script |
|------|--------|
| Run PRR checks | `Invoke-PRR.ps1` / `prr-check.sh` |

### Network Diagnostics (templates/network/)

| Task | Script (Windows) | Script (POSIX) | Config |
|------|------------------|----------------|--------|
| Port scanning | `Invoke-NetworkScan-v7.ps1` | `network-scan.sh` | `network.cfg` |
| DNS diagnostics | `Invoke-DnsDiagnostics-v7.ps1` | `dns-diagnostics.sh` | `network.cfg` |
| Network forensics | `Invoke-NetworkForensics-v7.ps1` | `network-forensics.sh` | `network.cfg` |
| Packet capture | `Invoke-PacketCapture-v7.ps1` (pktmon) | `packet-capture.sh` (tcpdump) | `network.cfg` |
| Background wrapper | `Invoke-BackgroundDiagnostics-v7.ps1` | (use nohup/&) | `network.cfg` |

Detects: DNS hijacking, ARP spoofing, LLMNR poisoning, suspicious connections, firewall issues.

### Linting (workspace root)

| Task | Script | Config |
|------|--------|--------|
| Aggregate linting | `lint-project.sh` / `Lint-Project-v5.ps1` / `Lint-Project-v7.ps1` | `lint.cfg` |

Runs C, Shell, PowerShell, JSON, YAML, Markdown linters plus ROSE-style policy checks:
- No tab characters in source files
- Maximum line length (default 132)
- Unix line endings (LF not CRLF)
- No "using" directives in headers

### Nuclei Vulnerability Scanning (nuclei-ops/)

| Task | Script | Config |
|------|--------|--------|
| Run nuclei scan | `nuclei-scan.sh` / `Invoke-NucleiScan-v5.ps1` / `Invoke-NucleiScan-v7.ps1` | `nuclei-scan.cfg` |

Features: Unified config for target, templates, rate limiting, output format. Auto-detects nuclei binary.

### Cursor Backup Extension (cursor-backup-ops/)

| Task | Script | Config |
|------|--------|--------|
| Install extension | `install-backup-extension.sh` / `Install-BackupExtension-v5.ps1` / `Install-BackupExtension-v7.ps1` | `backup-extension.cfg` |

Features: Builds TypeScript, packages VSIX, auto-detects IDE (Cursor/VS Code/Codium).

### Portmaster DNS Firewall (portmaster-ops/)

| Task | Script | Config |
|------|--------|--------|
| Status check | `portmaster-status.sh` / `Get-PortmasterStatus-v5.ps1` / `Get-PortmasterStatus-v7.ps1` | `portmaster.cfg` |
| Full diagnostics | `Invoke-PortmasterDiagnostics-v7.ps1` | `portmaster.cfg` |

### WSL2 KVM for Docker-OSX (wsl-kvm-ops/)

| Task | Script | Config |
|------|--------|--------|
| Enable features | `Install-WslKvm-v5.ps1 -Step Features` | `wsl-kvm.cfg` |
| Install distro | `Install-WslKvm-v5.ps1 -Step Distro` | `wsl-kvm.cfg` |
| Build KVM kernel | `Install-WslKvm-v5.ps1 -Step Kernel` | `wsl-kvm.cfg` |
| Configure WSL | `Install-WslKvm-v5.ps1 -Step Configure` | `wsl-kvm.cfg` |
| Setup Docker-OSX | `Install-WslKvm-v5.ps1 -Step DockerOsx` | `wsl-kvm.cfg` |
| Check status | `Install-WslKvm-v5.ps1 -Step Status` | `wsl-kvm.cfg` |

Workflow: Features (reboot) -> Distro -> Kernel -> Configure -> DockerOsx

Features:
- Detects if Portmaster is sole DNS resolver (`noAssignedNameservers: true`)
- Tests DoT (DNS-over-TLS) server connectivity
- Compares DNS resolution through Portmaster vs external servers
- Analyzes logs for blocked connections and resolver failures
- Identifies common DNS error patterns (0.0.0.17, .lan suffix, no compliant resolvers)

Key Portmaster paths:
- Config: `C:\ProgramData\Portmaster\config.json`
- Logs: `C:\ProgramData\Portmaster\logs\`
- UI: `http://127.0.0.1:817`

---

## Token Savings Example

**WITHOUT scripts** (agent generates each command):
```powershell
gh repo create owner/name --private
gh repo create owner/name-backup --private
cd /path/to/project
git init
git remote add origin https://github.com/owner/name.git
git remote add backup https://github.com/owner/name-backup.git
git add -A
git commit -s -m "Initial commit"
git branch -M main
git push -u origin main
git push backup main
```
**Tokens: ~800-1200**

**WITH scripts** (single invocation):
```powershell
.\git-ops\New-Repo.ps1 -Path "." -Private -WithBackup
```
**Tokens: ~50** (94% savings)

---

## Agent Instruction Files

Project-specific agent instructions are in `.copilot/` directories:

| Agent | Purpose | File |

| checks-agent | CI/CD monitoring | `checks-agent-instructions.md` |
| code-maintainer | C/ASM code quality | `code-maintainer-instructions.md` |

| docs-maintainer | Documentation quality | `docs-maintainer-instructions.md` |
| github-actions-agent | Workflow management | `github-actions-agent-instructions.md` |
| prd-agent | Requirements alignment | `prd-agent-instructions.md` |

| validator | Script/config validation | `validator-instructions.md` |
| workflow-maintainer | CI/CD configuration | `workflow-maintainer-instructions.md` |

---

## Template System

Templates in `templates/` use `{{VARIABLE}}` substitution:

- `templates/base/` - Common files (LICENSE, README, CONTRIBUTING)
- `templates/languages/` - Language-specific (c, python, rust, go, sh, powershell)
- `templates/ci-cd/` - CI/CD workflows (github-actions)
- `templates/platforms/` - Platform-specific

Invoke with:
```powershell
.\Invoke-Template.ps1 -ConfigFile project.cfg -Language c -OutputPath ./my-project
```

## Platform Detection

Scripts auto-detect platform and set defaults:

| Platform | Shell | Language | Assembly |

| Windows x64 | PowerShell | C17 | MASM/AMD64 |

---

## Before Generating Code

1. Check if a helper script exists for the task
2. Use `Search-Files.ps1` to find relevant templates
3. Use `Get-ProjectStructure.ps1` to understand layout
4. Read relevant `.copilot/*-instructions.md` files
5. Follow PRR guidelines for production readiness

---

## Background Execution for Long-Running Processes

When running scripts that have no definite end time (diagnostics, watchers, packet captures, servers), use background execution to avoid blocking the agent session.

### Problem

Agent tool calls timeout when scripts run too long. Scripts that:
- Collect data over extended periods (packet capture, forensics)
- Watch for file changes indefinitely
- Wait for network events
- Run servers or daemons

will cause `Tool call errored or timed out` errors.

### Solution: Background Wrapper Pattern

**Windows (PowerShell 7+):**
```powershell
# Use the background diagnostics wrapper
.\templates\network\Invoke-BackgroundDiagnostics-v7.ps1 -Script NetworkForensics -OutputPath .\results

# Or run any script in background with output capture
$job = Start-Job -ScriptBlock { & .\SomeLongScript.ps1 *>&1 | Tee-Object -FilePath .\output.txt }

# Check status later
Get-Content .\diagnostics-output\*-status.json
Get-Content .\diagnostics-output\*-stdout.txt
```

**Unix (POSIX sh):**
```sh
# Run with nohup and redirect output
nohup ./network-forensics.sh -o ./results > ./forensics.log 2>&1 &
echo $! > ./forensics.pid

# Check status later
cat ./forensics.log
kill -0 $(cat ./forensics.pid) && echo "Still running" || echo "Completed"
```

### Background Wrapper Scripts

| Task | Script | Output |
|------|--------|--------|
| Network diagnostics | `Invoke-BackgroundDiagnostics-v7.ps1` | `*-status.json`, `*-stdout.txt` |
| File watcher | `Watch-Project-v7.ps1` (run with Start-Job) | watcher.log |
| Packet capture | `Invoke-PacketCapture-v7.ps1` | ETL/PCAP files |

### Agent Workflow for Background Tasks

1. **Start**: Launch script with background wrapper, capture job/PID
2. **Continue**: Proceed with other tasks while script runs
3. **Check**: Read status file or stdout file to get results
4. **Retrieve**: Parse JSON output files for programmatic access

### Example: Network Diagnostics

```powershell
# Start forensics in background (returns immediately)
.\templates\network\Invoke-BackgroundDiagnostics-v7.ps1 -Script NetworkForensics -OutputPath .\forensics-results

# Do other work...

# Later, check results
Get-Content .\forensics-results\*-status.json | ConvertFrom-Json
Get-Content .\forensics-results\*-stdout.txt
Get-Content .\forensics-results\summary.json | ConvertFrom-Json
```

### Key Files After Background Execution

| File | Purpose |
|------|---------|
| `*-status.json` | Job state: Running/Completed/Failed, timestamps, exit code |
| `*-stdout.txt` | Captured console output |
| `*-stderr.txt` | Error output (if any) |
| `summary.json` | Structured results from the diagnostic script |

### Critical Rule

**DO NOT** run these scripts directly via `run_terminal_cmd` without background:
- `Invoke-NetworkForensics-v7.ps1`
- `Invoke-PacketCapture-v7.ps1`
- `Watch-Project-*.ps1`
- Any script with indefinite runtime

**DO** use `Invoke-BackgroundDiagnostics-v7.ps1` or `Start-Job` wrapper, then read output files.

---

## Config File Format

Universal `.cfg` files use `KEY=VALUE` format:

```
# Comment lines start with #
PROJECT_NAME=MyApp
TYPE=cli
LANGUAGE=c
AUTHOR=username
LICENSE=BSD-2-Clause
BACKUP_ENABLED=true
```

Parsed identically by all three script consumers.

---

## Validation Before Commit

Run these before declaring work complete:

```powershell
# Aggregate linting (uses lint.cfg)
.\Lint-Project-v7.ps1       # PowerShell 7+ (Windows/macOS/Linux)
.\Lint-Project-v5.ps1       # PowerShell 5.1 (Windows 10)
./lint-project.sh           # POSIX shell (macOS/Linux)
```

```sh
# Project-specific validation
./scripts/workflows.sh      # Validate GitHub Actions
./scripts/actions.sh        # Check action versions
./scripts/json-configs.sh   # Validate JSON files
./scripts/run-core-tests.sh # Run unit tests
```

---

## ROSE Policy Checkers

Integrated from `rose-1/scripts/policies/` (configure via `lint.cfg`):

| Config Key | Check |
|-----------|-------|
| `ROSE_NO_TABS` | No tab characters in source |
| `ROSE_MAX_LINE_LENGTH` | Lines <= N chars (default 132) |
| `ROSE_UNIX_LINE_ENDINGS` | LF only, no CRLF |
| `ROSE_NO_USING_IN_HEADERS` | No `using` directives in headers |
| `ROSE_CASE_INSENSITIVE_NAMES` | No files differing only by case |
| `ROSE_UNIQUE_HEADER_NAMES` | No duplicate header names |

Set `ROSE_SOURCE_EXTENSIONS` to control which files are checked.

---

## Required Reading for New Sessions

1. This file (`AGENT_ONBOARD.md`)
2. Project's `.cursorrules` if present
3. Project's `.copilot/` agent instructions if present
4. `git-ops/agent-instructions.md` for Git operations
5. `prr/agent-instructions-cursor.md` for production readiness

---

**DO NOT** generate multi-command sequences for:
- Project creation (use new-project scripts)
- Git repo setup (use git-ops scripts)
- Template processing (use Invoke-Template)
- File searching (use utils scripts)
- Production checks (use PRR scripts)

**DO** invoke single or multiple scripts with appropriate parameters for each.

---

**Example - Creating a New C Project:**

# RIGHT: Compose general tools

## Fravia Search Strategy + Suckless Principles

Apply reverse-engineering search methodology with minimal-complexity execution.

### Fravia Method: Search Strategy Formulation

Before searching, PLAN the search:

1. **Define the target** - What exactly are you looking for? (file, function, pattern, concept)
2. **Predict locations** - Where would this logically exist? (directory, file type, naming convention)
3. **Choose search depth** - Broad reconnaissance first, then targeted drilling
4. **Formulate patterns** - Build regex from known fragments, not guesses
5. **Cross-reference results** - Validate findings against multiple indicators

### Suckless Principles: Minimal Complexity, Maximum Effect

**AVOID** these anti-patterns (Useless Use of Cat and friends):

```sh
# BAD: UUoC - Useless Use of Cat
cat file.txt | grep pattern
cat file.txt | wc -l
cat file.txt | awk '{print $1}'
cat file.txt | sed 's/foo/bar/'

# GOOD: Direct invocation
grep pattern file.txt
wc -l < file.txt
awk '{print $1}' file.txt
sed 's/foo/bar/' file.txt
```

**AVOID** unnecessary tool chains:

```sh
# BAD: Multi-tool chain for simple task
cat file | grep foo | sed 's/bar/baz/' | awk '{print $2}' | wc -l

# GOOD: Single tool when possible
awk '/foo/ { gsub(/bar/, "baz"); print $2; count++ } END { print count }' file
```

**PREFER** heredoc and ed/vi for edits:

```sh
# BAD: Multiple sed invocations
sed -i 's/old1/new1/' file
sed -i 's/old2/new2/' file
sed -i 's/old3/new3/' file

# GOOD: Single heredoc with ed
ed -s file <<'EOF'
%s/old1/new1/g
%s/old2/new2/g
%s/old3/new3/g
w
q
EOF

# GOOD: Single sed with multiple expressions
sed -i -e 's/old1/new1/g' -e 's/old2/new2/g' -e 's/old3/new3/g' file
```

### Search Tool Priority

Use tools in this order (most efficient first):

| Priority | Tool | Use Case |
|----------|------|----------|
| 1 | `grep -r` / `rg` | Known pattern, broad search |
| 2 | `find` + `-name` | Known filename pattern |
| 3 | `git grep` | Within git repo, respects .gitignore |
| 4 | Codebase semantic search | Concept/meaning-based queries |
| 5 | Web search | External documentation, APIs |

### PowerShell Equivalents

```powershell
# BAD: Pipeline abuse
Get-Content file.txt | Select-String pattern
Get-Content file.txt | Measure-Object -Line
Get-Content file.txt | ForEach-Object { $_.Split()[0] }

# GOOD: Direct parameter usage
Select-String -Path file.txt -Pattern pattern
(Get-Content file.txt).Count
(Get-Content file.txt) -replace 'pattern', 'replacement'

# GOOD: Single expression for complex operations
Get-Content file.txt | ForEach-Object -Begin { $count = 0 } -Process {
    if ($_ -match 'pattern') { $count++ }
} -End { $count }
```

### The Suckless Test

Before executing a command chain, ask:

1. Can this be done with ONE tool instead of many?
2. Am I piping cat/Get-Content unnecessarily?
3. Would a heredoc/here-string be cleaner?
4. Is there a built-in flag that eliminates a pipeline stage?
5. Am I using awk/sed when grep alone suffices (or vice versa)?

**Rule of thumb:** If your command has more than 2 pipes, reconsider the approach."}

## RESOLVED: Agent Shell Bug Workaround (Windows 11)

**Status:** RESOLVED as of 2025-12-14. Shell tool now works correctly.

**History:** Between 2025-12-07 and 2025-12-14, Cursor Shell tool returned `pid: -1` on Windows 11 (build 26200, Cursor 2.1.50+). This has been fixed.

### File-Based Shell Bridge (Archived - For Reference Only)

The bridge workaround below is no longer needed but preserved for reference if the issue recurs.

<details>
<summary>Click to expand archived workaround</summary>

When the Cursor Shell tool fails, use `agent-shell-bridge.ps1` which runs in the user's manual terminal.

**To execute shell commands:**

1. Write command to `.agent-command.txt` using the Write tool
2. Wait briefly, then read `.agent-status.txt` (should say `DONE`)
3. Read result from `.agent-result.txt`

**Example:**

```
# Step 1: Write command
Write tool -> .agent-command.txt -> "hostname; Get-Date"

# Step 2: Check status
Read tool -> .agent-status.txt -> "DONE"

# Step 3: Read result
Read tool -> .agent-result.txt -> "EXIT_CODE=0\nDESKTOP-7KTB236\n..."
```

**Files:**

| File | Purpose |
|------|---------|
| `.agent-command.txt` | Write your command here (bridge consumes it) |
| `.agent-status.txt` | READY/RUNNING/DONE |
| `.agent-result.txt` | EXIT_CODE=N followed by output |
| `agent-shell-bridge.ps1` | The bridge script (user starts once) |

</details>

## Background Execution for Long-Running Processes

When running scripts that have no definite end time (diagnostics, watchers, packet captures, servers), use background execution to avoid blocking the agent session.

### Problem

Agent tool calls timeout when scripts run too long. Scripts that:
- Collect data over extended periods (packet capture, forensics)
- Watch for file changes indefinitely
- Wait for network events
- Run servers or daemons

will cause `Tool call errored or timed out` errors.

### Solution: Background Wrapper Pattern

**Windows (PowerShell 7+):**
```powershell
# Use the background diagnostics wrapper
.\templates\network\Invoke-BackgroundDiagnostics-v7.ps1 -Script NetworkForensics -OutputPath .\results

# Or run any script in background with output capture
$job = Start-Job -ScriptBlock { & .\SomeLongScript.ps1 *>&1 | Tee-Object -FilePath .\output.txt }

# Check status later
Get-Content .\diagnostics-output\*-status.json
Get-Content .\diagnostics-output\*-stdout.txt
```

**Unix (POSIX sh):**
```sh
# Run with nohup and redirect output
nohup ./network-forensics.sh -o ./results > ./forensics.log 2>&1 &
echo $! > ./forensics.pid

# Check status later
cat ./forensics.log
kill -0 $(cat ./forensics.pid) && echo "Still running" || echo "Completed"
```

### Background Wrapper Scripts

| Task | Script | Output |
|------|--------|--------|
| Network diagnostics | `Invoke-BackgroundDiagnostics-v7.ps1` | `*-status.json`, `*-stdout.txt` |
| File watcher | `Watch-Project-v7.ps1` (run with Start-Job) | watcher.log |
| Packet capture | `Invoke-PacketCapture-v7.ps1` | ETL/PCAP files |

### Agent Workflow for Background Tasks

1. **Start**: Launch script with background wrapper, capture job/PID
2. **Continue**: Proceed with other tasks while script runs
3. **Check**: Read status file or stdout file to get results
4. **Retrieve**: Parse JSON output files for programmatic access

### Example: Network Diagnostics

```powershell
# Start forensics in background (returns immediately)
.\templates\network\Invoke-BackgroundDiagnostics-v7.ps1 -Script NetworkForensics -OutputPath .\forensics-results

# Do other work...

# Later, check results
Get-Content .\forensics-results\*-status.json | ConvertFrom-Json
Get-Content .\forensics-results\*-stdout.txt
Get-Content .\forensics-results\summary.json | ConvertFrom-Json
```

### Key Files After Background Execution

| File | Purpose |
|------|---------|
| `*-status.json` | Job state: Running/Completed/Failed, timestamps, exit code |
| `*-stdout.txt` | Captured console output |
| `*-stderr.txt` | Error output (if any) |
| `summary.json` | Structured results from the diagnostic script |

### Critical Rule

**DO NOT** run these scripts directly via `run_terminal_cmd` without background:
- `Invoke-NetworkForensics-v7.ps1`
- `Invoke-PacketCapture-v7.ps1`
- `Watch-Project-*.ps1`
- Any script with indefinite runtime

**DO** use `Invoke-BackgroundDiagnostics-v7.ps1` or `Start-Job` wrapper, then read output files.

---

## Config File Format

Universal `.cfg` files use `KEY=VALUE` format:

```
# Comment lines start with #
PROJECT_NAME=MyApp
TYPE=cli
LANGUAGE=c
AUTHOR=username
LICENSE=BSD-2-Clause
BACKUP_ENABLED=true
```

Parsed identically by all three script consumers.

---

## Validation Before Commit

Run these before declaring work complete:

```powershell
# Aggregate linting (uses lint.cfg)
.\Lint-Project-v7.ps1       # PowerShell 7+ (Windows/macOS/Linux)
.\Lint-Project-v5.ps1       # PowerShell 5.1 (Windows 10)
./lint-project.sh           # POSIX shell (macOS/Linux)
```

```sh
# Project-specific validation
./scripts/workflows.sh      # Validate GitHub Actions
./scripts/actions.sh        # Check action versions
./scripts/json-configs.sh   # Validate JSON files
./scripts/run-core-tests.sh # Run unit tests
```

---

## ROSE Policy Checkers

Integrated from `rose-1/scripts/policies/` (configure via `lint.cfg`):

| Config Key | Check |
|-----------|-------|
| `ROSE_NO_TABS` | No tab characters in source |
| `ROSE_MAX_LINE_LENGTH` | Lines <= N chars (default 132) |
| `ROSE_UNIX_LINE_ENDINGS` | LF only, no CRLF |
| `ROSE_NO_USING_IN_HEADERS` | No `using` directives in headers |
| `ROSE_CASE_INSENSITIVE_NAMES` | No files differing only by case |
| `ROSE_UNIQUE_HEADER_NAMES` | No duplicate header names |

Set `ROSE_SOURCE_EXTENSIONS` to control which files are checked.

---

## Required Reading for New Sessions

1. This file (`AGENT_ONBOARD.md`)
2. Project's `.cursorrules` if present
3. Project's `.copilot/` agent instructions if present
4. `git-ops/agent-instructions.md` for Git operations
5. `prr/agent-instructions-cursor.md` for production readiness

---

**DO NOT** generate multi-command sequences for:
- Project creation (use new-project scripts)
- Git repo setup (use git-ops scripts)
- Template processing (use Invoke-Template)
- File searching (use utils scripts)
- Production checks (use PRR scripts)

**DO** invoke single or multiple scripts with appropriate parameters for each.

---

Generated: 2025-12-01
Updated: 2025-12-14 (shell bug resolved)
Purpose: Agent onboarding for token efficiency

"}

codeBlocks.content:
# start-llm.ps1 - Launch local LLM server for Cursor
# RTX 4060 8GB VRAM-safe settings

$ErrorActionPreference = "Stop"
Set-Location $PSScriptRoot

$model = "qwen2.5-coder-7b-instruct-q4_k_m.gguf"

if (-not (Test-Path $model)) {
    Write-Host "ERROR: Model not found: $model" -ForegroundColor Red
    Write-Host "Download from: https://huggingface.co/Qwen/Qwen2.5-Coder-7B-Instruct-GGUF"
    exit 1
}

Write-Host "Starting llamafile server..." -ForegroundColor Cyan
Write-Host "Model: $model"
Write-Host "Endpoint: http://127.0.0.1:8080/v1"
Write-Host ""
Write-Host "Press Ctrl+C to stop"
Write-Host ""

# RTX 4060 8GB VRAM-safe settings:
# -ngl 99       = Full GPU offload (all layers to VRAM)
# -c 4096       = 4K context (safer than 8K on 8GB with Windows+Cursor overhead)
# --host/--port = OpenAI-compatible API on localhost
# --nobrowser   = Silent start (no browser tab)

.\llamafile.exe `
    -m $model `
    -ngl 99 `
    -c 4096 `
    --host 127.0.0.1 `
    --port 8080 `
    --nobrowser

2. Key Technical Concepts:
- **NTFS (New Technology File System)**: Default file system for modern Windows OS.
- **Windows Recovery Environment (WinRE)**: Minimal Windows OS for system repair.
- **Disk Partitioning**: Dividing a hard drive into logical units.
- **GPT (GUID Partition Table)**: Partition table standard.
- **PowerShell Scripting**: Automation for system administration.
- **`reagentc`**: Command-line tool for WinRE configuration.
- **`diskpart`**: Utility for disk partition management.
- **`winget`**: Windows Package Manager.
- **`.cursor rules` / `AGENT_ONBOARD.md` / Agent Hooks**: AI agent operational guidelines.
- **`gh` CLI**: GitHub command-line interface.
- **LLM (Large Language Model)**: AI model for language tasks.
- **Llamafile**: A single-file executable for running LLMs locally, based on Cosmopolitan C and llama.cpp.
- **GGUF**: A file format for storing LLMs, optimized for llama.cpp.
- **OpenAI API Protocol**: A standardized HTTP API for interacting with LLMs, adopted by many local LLM servers.
- **Hugging Face MCP (Model Context Protocol)**: A protocol/tool for AI assistants to interact with the Hugging Face Hub (models, datasets, tools).
- **CUDA**: NVIDIA's platform for parallel computing on GPUs.
- **PyTorch**: An open-source machine learning framework.
- **`uv`**: A fast Python package installer and resolver.
- **VRAM (Video RAM)**: Memory on the GPU.
- **Context Window**: The maximum number of tokens an LLM can process at once.

data.text:
**Llamafile server is running.**

## Status Summary:

- Server running: `http://127.0.0.1:8080/v1`
- API test: SUCCESS (responded with "Hello!")
- Cursor config: Base URL set to `http://127.0.0.1:8080/v1` in `settings.json`

## Next Steps:

1. Restart Cursor completely (close all windows, then reopen) to load the new Base URL setting.
2. Verify in Cursor Settings:
   - Press `Ctrl+,`
   - Search for "openai" or "base"
   - Confirm it shows `http://127.0.0.1:8080/v1`
3. Test in Cursor:
   - Try a small code completion (Ctrl+K on a selection)
   - Or use Chat (Ctrl+L) with a simple prompt
   - The local Qwen model should respond

## Model Configuration:

When using the local model in Cursor, use:
- Model ID: `qwen2.5-coder-7b-instruct-q4_k_m.gguf` (or `local-qwen-7b` if you set that alias)

The server will continue running in the background. To stop it, find the PowerShell process running `llamafile.exe` and terminate it, or restart your terminal session.

Ready to test in Cursor?

data.richText: {"root":{"children":[{"children":[{"detail":0,"format":0,"mode":"normal","style":"","text":"You have a very solid plan now. By pivoting to **llamafile** (Cosmopolitan C) for the local LLM and restricting **MCP** to the remote-only built-in tool, you sidestep the \"Python/PyTorch Blob\" problem entirely.","type":"text","version":1}],"direction":"ltr","format":"","indent":0,"type":"paragraph","version":1},{"children":[],"direction":null,"format":"","indent":0,"type":"paragraph","version":1},{"children":[{"detail":0,"format":0,"mode":"normal","style":"","text":"Here is the final, polished prompt to paste into Cursor. It includes the specific download instructions and cleanup steps to get your system back to a clean state.","type":"text","version":1}],"direction":"ltr","format":"","indent":0,"type":"paragraph","version":1},{"children":[],"direction":null,"format":"","indent":0,"type":"paragraph","version":1},{"children":[{"detail":0,"format":0,"mode":"normal","style":"","text":"---","type":"text","version":1}],"direction":null,"format":"","indent":0,"type":"paragraph","version":1},{"children":[],"direction":null,"format":"","indent":0,"type":"paragraph","version":1},{"children":[{"detail":0,"format":0,"mode":"normal","style":"","text":"### The Prompt to Copy/Paste into Cursor Chat (Ctrl+L)","type":"text","version":1}],"direction":"ltr","format":"","indent":0,"type":"paragraph","version":1},{"children":[],"direction":null,"format":"","indent":0,"type":"paragraph","version":1},{"children":[{"detail":0,"format":0,"mode":"normal","style":"","text":"```markdown","type":"text","version":1}],"direction":"ltr","format":"","indent":0,"type":"paragraph","version":1},{"children":[{"detail":0,"format":0,"mode":"normal","style":"","text":"I am re-architecting my local LLM setup for a Windows 11 machine with strict resource constraints (16GB RAM, RTX 4060 8GB VRAM).","type":"text","version":1}],"direction":"ltr","format":"","indent":0,"type":"paragraph","version":1},{"children":[],"direction":null,"format":"","indent":0,"type":"paragraph","version":1},{"children":[{"detail":0,"format":0,"mode":"normal","style":"","text":"We will use a **\"Sandwich\" Architecture**:","type":"text","version":1}],"direction":"ltr","format":"","indent":0,"type":"paragraph","version":1},{"children":[{"detail":0,"format":0,"mode":"normal","style":"","text":"1.  **Local \"Finisher\" LLM:** A **Llamafile** (Qwen 2.5 Coder 7B) running as an OpenAI-compatible server. This keeps inference 100% in VRAM and avoids Python bloat.","type":"text","version":1}],"direction":"ltr","format":"","indent":0,"type":"paragraph","version":1},{"children":[{"detail":0,"format":0,"mode":"normal","style":"","text":"2.  **Context Tool:** The **Built-in Hugging Face MCP tool** (already installed in Cursor), configured strictly for **Remote API** access (Search/Inspect) to avoid local RAM usage.","type":"text","version":1}],"direction":"ltr","format":"","indent":0,"type":"paragraph","version":1},{"children":[],"direction":null,"format":"","indent":0,"type":"paragraph","version":1},{"children":[{"detail":0,"format":0,"mode":"normal","style":"","text":"Please provide a comprehensive PowerShell guide to implement this:","type":"text","version":1}],"direction":"ltr","format":"","indent":0,"type":"paragraph","version":1},{"children":[],"direction":null,"format":"","indent":0,"type":"paragraph","version":1},{"children":[{"detail":0,"format":0,"mode":"normal","style":"","text":"### Part 1: Cleanup (Critical)","type":"text","version":1}],"direction":"ltr","format":"","indent":0,"type":"paragraph","version":1},{"children":[{"detail":0,"format":0,"mode":"normal","style":"","text":"*   Provide PowerShell commands to delete the `huggingface-mcp` folder and any associated venvs created by previous attempts.","type":"text","version":1}],"direction":"ltr","format":"","indent":0,"type":"paragraph","version":1},{"children":[{"detail":0,"format":0,"mode":"normal","style":"","text":"*   Confirm that I should **keep** `uv` (installed globally) as it is lightweight.","type":"text","version":1}],"direction":"ltr","format":"","indent":0,"type":"paragraph","version":1},{"children":[],"direction":null,"format":"","indent":0,"type":"paragraph","version":1},{"children":[{"detail":0,"format":0,"mode":"normal","style":"","text":"### Part 2: The Llamafile Setup (The \"Glue\")","type":"text","version":1}],"direction":"ltr","format":"","indent":0,"type":"paragraph","version":1},{"children":[{"detail":0,"format":0,"mode":"normal","style":"","text":"1.  Provide the PowerShell commands to create a folder `C:\\llamafile-llm`.","type":"text","version":1}],"direction":"ltr","format":"","indent":0,"type":"paragraph","version":1},{"children":[{"detail":0,"format":0,"mode":"normal","style":"","text":"2.  Provide the direct download URL (or specific GitHub Release asset name) for the latest `llamafile-server.exe` (Cosmopolitan binary) and command to rename it to `server.exe`.","type":"text","version":1}],"direction":"ltr","format":"","indent":0,"type":"paragraph","version":1},{"children":[{"detail":0,"format":0,"mode":"normal","style":"","text":"3.  Provide the URL/Command to download `Qwen2.5-Coder-7B-Instruct-Q4_K_M.gguf` (approx 4.7GB).","type":"text","version":1}],"direction":"ltr","format":"","indent":0,"type":"paragraph","version":1},{"children":[{"detail":0,"format":0,"mode":"normal","style":"","text":"4.  Generate a `start-llm.ps1` script with these EXACT flags for my RTX 4060:","type":"text","version":1}],"direction":"ltr","format":"","indent":0,"type":"paragraph","version":1},{"children":[{"detail":0,"format":0,"mode":"normal","style":"","text":"    ```powershell","type":"text","version":1}],"direction":"ltr","format":"","indent":0,"type":"paragraph","version":1},{"children":[{"detail":0,"format":0,"mode":"normal","style":"","text":"    .\\server.exe -m Qwen2.5-Coder-7B-Instruct-Q4_K_M.gguf -ngl 999 -c 8192 --host 127.0.0.1 --port 8080 --n-gpu-layers 35","type":"text","version":1}],"direction":"ltr","format":"","indent":0,"type":"paragraph","version":1},{"children":[{"detail":0,"format":0,"mode":"normal","style":"","text":"    ```","type":"text","version":1}],"direction":null,"format":"","indent":0,"type":"paragraph","version":1},{"children":[{"detail":0,"format":0,"mode":"normal","style":"","text":"    *(Explain briefly why `-ngl 999` is safe for the 4060).*","type":"text","version":1}],"direction":"ltr","format":"","indent":0,"type":"paragraph","version":1},{"children":[],"direction":null,"format":"","indent":0,"type":"paragraph","version":1},{"children":[{"detail":0,"format":0,"mode":"normal","style":"","text":"### Part 3: The MCP Configuration (The \"Context\")","type":"text","version":1}],"direction":"ltr","format":"","indent":0,"type":"paragraph","version":1},{"children":[{"detail":0,"format":0,"mode":"normal","style":"","text":"1.  Show me the exact JSON content for `%USERPROFILE%\\.cursor\\mcp.json`.","type":"text","version":1}],"direction":"ltr","format":"","indent":0,"type":"paragraph","version":1},{"children":[{"detail":0,"format":0,"mode":"normal","style":"","text":"2.  It must use the existing \"Hugging Face\" entry but I need to know where to add the `HF_TOKEN` environment variable so it uses the **Remote Inference API** instead of downloading models locally.","type":"text","version":1}],"direction":"ltr","format":"","indent":0,"type":"paragraph","version":1},{"children":[{"detail":0,"format":0,"mode":"normal","style":"","text":"    *   *Constraint:* Do not instruct me to install a new MCP server. Configure the built-in one.","type":"text","version":1}],"direction":"ltr","format":"","indent":0,"type":"paragraph","version":1},{"children":[],"direction":null,"format":"","indent":0,"type":"paragraph","version":1},{"children":[{"detail":0,"format":0,"mode":"normal","style":"","text":"### Part 4: Cursor Integration","type":"text","version":1}],"direction":"ltr","format":"","indent":0,"type":"paragraph","version":1},{"children":[{"detail":0,"format":0,"mode":"normal","style":"","text":"1.  Step-by-step instructions to add the Llamafile server to **Settings > Models**:","type":"text","version":1}],"direction":"ltr","format":"","indent":0,"type":"paragraph","version":1},{"children":[{"detail":0,"format":0,"mode":"normal","style":"","text":"    *   Base URL: `http://127.0.0.1:8080/v1`","type":"text","version":1}],"direction":"ltr","format":"","indent":0,"type":"paragraph","version":1},{"children":[{"detail":0,"format":0,"mode":"normal","style":"","text":"    *   Model Name: (Specify what Llamafile expects, e.g., `user-specified` or the filename).","type":"text","version":1}],"direction":"ltr","format":"","indent":0,"type":"paragraph","version":1},{"children":[{"detail":0,"format":0,"mode":"normal","style":"","text":"2.  Provide a **System Prompt** for Cursor \"Rules for AI\" that enforces the \"Finisher\" role:","type":"text","version":1}],"direction":"ltr","format":"","indent":0,"type":"paragraph","version":1},{"children":[{"detail":0,"format":0,"mode":"normal","style":"","text":"    *   \"You are a local code completion engine. Output ONLY code. Do not explain. data.text:
You have a very solid plan now. By pivoting to **llamafile** (Cosmopolitan C) for the local LLM and restricting **MCP** to the remote-only built-in tool, you sidestep the "Python/PyTorch Blob" problem entirely.



Here is the final, polished prompt to paste into Cursor. It includes the specific download instructions and cleanup steps to get your system back to a clean state.

---

### The Prompt to Copy/Paste into Cursor Chat (Ctrl+L)

```markdown

I am re-architecting my local LLM setup for a Windows 11 machine with strict resource constraints (16GB RAM, RTX 4060 8GB VRAM).

We will use a **"Sandwich" Architecture**:

1.  **Local "Finisher" LLM:** A **Llamafile** (Qwen 2.5 Coder 7B) running as an OpenAI-compatible server. This keeps inference 100% in VRAM and avoids Python bloat.

2.  **Context Tool:** The **Built-in Hugging Face MCP tool** (already installed in Cursor), configured strictly for **Remote API** access (Search/Inspect) to avoid local RAM usage.

Please provide a comprehensive PowerShell guide to implement this:

### Part 1: Cleanup (Critical)

*   Provide PowerShell commands to delete the `huggingface-mcp` folder and any associated venvs created by previous attempts.

*   Confirm that I should **keep** `uv` (installed globally) as it is lightweight.

### Part 2: The Llamafile Setup (The "Glue")

1.  Provide the PowerShell commands to create a folder `C:\llamafile-llm`.

2.  Provide the direct download URL (or specific GitHub Release asset name) for the latest `llamafile-server.exe` (Cosmopolitan binary) and command to rename it to `server.exe`.

3.  Provide the URL/Command to download `Qwen2.5-Coder-7B-Instruct-Q4_K_M.gguf` (approx 4.7GB).

4.  Generate a `start-llm.ps1` script with these EXACT flags for my RTX 4060:

    ```powershell

    .\server.exe -m Qwen2.5-Coder-7B-Instruct-Q4_K_M.gguf -ngl 999 -c 8192 --host 127.0.0.1 --port 8080 --n-gpu-layers 35

    ```

    *(Explain briefly why `-ngl 999` is safe for the 4060).*

### Part 3: The MCP Configuration (The "Context")

1.  Show me the exact JSON content for `%USERPROFILE%\.cursor\mcp.json`.

2.  It must use the existing "Hugging Face" entry but I need to know where to add the `HF_TOKEN` environment variable so it uses the **Remote Inference API** instead of downloading models locally.

    *   *Constraint:* Do not instruct me to install a new MCP server. Configure the built-in one.

### Part 4: Cursor Integration

1.  Step-by-step instructions to add the Llamafile server to **Settings > Models**:

    *   Base URL: `http://127.0.0.1:8080/v1`

    *   Model Name: (Specify what Llamafile expects, e.g., `user-specified` or the filename).

2.  Provide a **System Prompt** for Cursor "Rules for AI" that enforces the "Finisher" role:

    *   "You are a local code completion engine. Output ONLY code. Do not explain. Do not chat."

**Goal:** A setup where the Local LLM consumes ~5GB VRAM and <200MB System RAM, leaving system memory free for the Cursor Indexer and Compiler Toolchains.

```

### What happens next?

1.  **Run the Cleanup:** Delete that heavy venv folder immediately.

2.  **Download Llamafile:** ItΓÇÖs a single ~30MB binary.

3.  **Run the Script:** Your GPU memory usage will jump to ~5GB. Your System RAM will barely move.

4.  **Connect Cursor:** You will have blazing fast, free, local autocomplete that respects your privacy and your hardware limits.



HereΓÇÖs a cleaned, oneΓÇæshot prompt you can paste into **Cursor Chat (Ctrl+L)** to get its LLM to set up:



- A **local llamafile LLM** (7B code model) as the **finisher/glue**, and  

- Keep the **builtΓÇæin Hugging Face MCP tool** for **remote context only**, not local inference.

---

### Prompt for Cursor IDE LLM: local llamafile + existing Hugging Face MCP

```text

You previously helped set up a heavy Python + PyTorch + transformers stack and wired CursorΓÇÖs MCP to Hugging FaceΓÇÖs remote MCP server at "https://huggingface.co/mcp". ThatΓÇÖs fine for remote Hugging Face tools, but it is NOT what I want for my main local LLM.

I want to reΓÇæarchitect this cleanly around TWO things:

1. A **local llamafile HTTP server** running a small 7B code model on my GPU, exposed via an **OpenAIΓÇæcompatible API**, and registered in CursorΓÇÖs Models as my ΓÇ£local finisherΓÇ¥.

2. The **existing builtΓÇæin Hugging Face MCP tool** remaining as a remote context provider (Hub search, Spaces, docs/snippets) ΓÇô NOT as a local inference bridge.

DO NOT:

- Reinstall or reconfigure Python, PyTorch, or transformers for my main code model.

- Create any new MCP servers beyond the builtΓÇæin Hugging Face MCP entry.

- Try to run large transformer models or embeddings locally via MCP.

You may assume:

- OS: Windows 11 Pro (x64)

- CPU: AMD Ryzen 7 7700

- GPU: NVIDIA RTX 4060, 8 GB VRAM

- RAM: 16 GB

- Cursor: latest version with **Hugging Face MCP already configured** in `%USERPROFILE%\.cursor\mcp.json` pointing to `https://huggingface.co/mcp`

- Python + uv + torch + transformers are on disk from a previous attempt, but I do NOT want a longΓÇærunning Python inference server.

GOAL

----

Set up a **llamafileΓÇæbased local LLM** as a separate HTTP server, and configure Cursor to use it as a custom OpenAIΓÇæcompatible model for fast, fileΓÇælocal edits. Keep Hugging Face MCP asΓÇæis for remote context.

LOCAL MODEL REQUIREMENTS

------------------------

- Model: a **7BΓÇæclass code model**, Q4/Q5 quantized, suitable for:

  - C, sh, small AMD64/AArch64 asm snippets

  - JS, CSS, HTML, PHP

  - Python, Java, Rust

  - CMake, Cargo, Gradle, MSBuild, Dockerfiles, Ansible/Terraform YAML, etc.

- Example: `Qwen2.5-Coder-7B-Instruct-Q4_K_M.gguf` or a similar 7B code GGUF.

- Runtime: **llamafile** (Cosmopolitan C + llama.cpp) running in HTTP server mode.

- Context length: ~8k tokens.

- Must fit entirely in 8 GB VRAM, with low additional system RAM use.

WHAT I WANT YOU TO DO

---------------------

Produce a **concrete, stepΓÇæbyΓÇæstep setup** with PowerShell commands and config snippets.

### Part 1 ΓÇô Clarify what from the old setup is optional

1. Explain which parts of the earlier Python/torch setup are now optional and can be ignored. Do NOT delete anything automatically, but:

   - Point out that any `huggingface-mcp/.venv` directory is not needed for my main local LLM.

   - Make clear that the existing `%USERPROFILE%\.cursor\mcp.json` entry for "Hugging Face" pointing to `https://huggingface.co/mcp` is fine and should be left in place as my remote MCP tool.

2. Explicitly confirm:

   - The Hugging Face MCP entry will remain a **remote tool only**.

   - It will NOT try to host or run my local llamafile model.

### Part 2 ΓÇô Set up llamafile + GGUF model

Assume I will put everything in `C:\llamafile-llm\`.

1. Provide PowerShell commands to:

   - Create the folder and cd into it:

     ```powershell

     New-Item -ItemType Directory -Path C:\llamafile-llm -Force | Out-Null

     cd C:\llamafile-llm

     ```

   - Download the llamafile binary (e.g., `llamafile.exe`) from the official GitHub releases page.

     - If you canΓÇÖt give the exact URL, write a placeholder like:

       - ΓÇ£Download the latest Windows x86_64 llamafile release from the Mozilla/llamafile GitHub releases page and save it here as `llamafile.exe`.ΓÇ¥

   - Download a suitable 7B code GGUF (e.g., `Qwen2.5-Coder-7B-Instruct-Q4_K_M.gguf`) from Hugging Face.

     - If you canΓÇÖt give the exact direct URL, specify the repo name (e.g., `TheBloke/Qwen2.5-Coder-7B-Instruct-GGUF`) and approximate filename and note that I should download that file into `C:\llamafile-llm\`.

2. Provide a `start-llm.ps1` script that:

   - Changes to `C:\llamafile-llm`.

   - Starts llamafile in HTTP server mode with flags tuned for my RTX 4060 and 16GB RAM, for example:

     ```powershell

     cd C:\llamafile-llm

     .\llamafile.exe `

       -m Qwen2.5-Coder-7B-Instruct-Q4_K_M.gguf `

       -ngl 99 `

       -c 8192 `

       --host 127.0.0.1 `

       --port 8080

     ```

   - Briefly explain:

     - `-m` = model GGUF file name.

     - `-ngl 99` = offload all possible layers to GPU (appropriate for 8 GB VRAM).

     - `-c 8192` = 8k token context, safe for a 7B Q4/Q5 model on 8 GB VRAM.

     - `--host/--port` = listen on `http://127.0.0.1:8080`.

3. Confirm that llamafileΓÇÖs HTTP API is **OpenAIΓÇæcompatible**, especially:

   - `POST /v1/chat/completions`

   - Clarify what ΓÇ£modelΓÇ¥ name the API expects in the request:

     - Either a dummy string I choose (e.g., `"local-qwen-7b"`), or

     - The GGUF filename.

   - Show a minimal example `curl` or PowerShell `Invoke-RestMethod` call against `http://127.0.0.1:8080/v1/chat/completions` to verify the server.

### Part 3 ΓÇô Register llamafile as a custom model in Cursor

1. Show me how to configure CursorΓÇÖs **Models** settings so that it recognizes llamafile as a custom OpenAIΓÇæcompatible model:

   - Base URL: `http://127.0.0.1:8080/v1`

   - API key: any dummy string (if required by UI; llamafile will ignore it).

   - Model name: the one llamafile expects (from Part 2, e.g., `local-qwen-7b` or the GGUF name).

   Provide a short, numbered list:

   1. Open Cursor Settings ΓåÆ **Models**.

   2. Click to add a new **OpenAIΓÇæcompatible** model.

   3. Set:

      - Base URL to `http://127.0.0.1:8080/v1`

      - Model name as decided above.

      - Dummy API key (if Cursor requires one).

   4. Save and test with a small oneΓÇæline prompt or a Ctrl+K edit on a single function.

2. Explain how I should **use** this model in Cursor:

   - For **Ctrl+K (Edit)** on single files or selections:

     - Choose this llamafileΓÇæbacked model (e.g., ΓÇ£localΓÇæqwenΓÇæ7bΓÇ¥) as the model.

     - It should act as my fast ΓÇ£finisher/glueΓÇ¥ engine.

   - For **Ctrl+L (Chat)** and multiΓÇæfile reasoning:

     - Keep using my SaaS model (e.g., Claude 3.5 Sonnet / Opus).

   - For TabΓÇæbased inline completions:

     - ItΓÇÖs fine to keep using CursorΓÇÖs default cloud autocomplete.

3. Provide a recommended **system prompt / behavior description** for the local model in this role, for example:

   > ΓÇ£You are a fast, local code finisher running inside an alreadyΓÇæscaffolded project. Only generate or modify the minimal code or configuration requested in the userΓÇÖs selection or prompt. Do NOT reΓÇæemit entire files unless explicitly asked. Do not explain; output only code or configuration that fits into the existing file.ΓÇ¥

### Part 4 ΓÇô Hugging Face MCP: clarify and keep it lightweight

1. Reiterate briefly what my current Hugging Face MCP config does, e.g.:

   ```json

   "Hugging Face": {

     "url": "https://huggingface.co/mcp",

     "headers": {

       "Authorization": "Bearer hf_...TOKEN..."

     }

   }

   ```

   and confirm that:

   - This points to a **remote MCP server** at Hugging Face.

   - It is good for Hub/Spaces tools (search, examples, lightweight context).

   - It does **not** run heavy models locally by default.

{"contents":"# start-llm.ps1 - Launch local LLM server for Cursor
# RTX 4060 8GB optimized settings

$ErrorActionPreference = "Stop"
Set-Location $PSScriptRoot

$model = "qwen2.5-coder-7b-instruct-q4_k_m.gguf"

if (-not (Test-Path $model)) {
    Write-Host "ERROR: Model not found: $model" -ForegroundColor Red
    Write-Host "Download from: https://huggingface.co/Qwen/Qwen2.5-Coder-7B-Instruct-GGUF"
    exit 1
}

Write-Host "Starting llamafile server..." -ForegroundColor Cyan
Write-Host "Model: $model"
Write-Host "Endpoint: http://127.0.0.1:8080/v1"
Write-Host ""
Write-Host "Press Ctrl+C to stop"
Write-Host ""

# RTX 4060 8GB settings:
# -ngl 99       = Offload all layers to GPU (7B Q4 fits in 8GB with room to spare)
# -c 8192       = 8K context window (safe for 8GB VRAM)
# --host/--port = OpenAI-compatible API on localhost
# -t 8          = Use 8 CPU threads for any CPU-bound ops (Ryzen 7 7700 has 8 cores)

.\llamafile.exe `
    -m $model `
    -ngl 99 `
    -c 8192 `
    -t 8 `
    --host 127.0.0.1 `
    --port 8080
